Posted: December 28, 2013
												A good game.It's very simple, a mash up of classic PC sci-fi flightsims like Freespacer as well as arcadey games like Star Fox. In fact, I'd say those specifically. High paced, lots of bloom and explosions as you shread through tons of foes. The game is very mindless - the story is a excuse plot (In a war between EARF and COLONIALS,♥♥♥♥♥♥got real and now it's up to YOU to stop the destruction blah blah) with about four characters in all, but it's not about the story. It's not about being thought out and tactical, it's about you in a super ship that can turn into a robot suit for a limited time and murder everyone in the immediate area. It's about your headphones being a blurr of missile beeps, low energy explosions, objective chatter and explosions all at once.It's also a game that (harmlessly) takes the♥♥♥♥♥♥out on you if you don't meet it's rather the rather strict score requirements of its medals/ranks. ("THOSE♥♥♥♥♥♥EARF PILOTS DIDN'T DO JACK" vs "OH JESUS CHRIST.")It's cheap, fun and simple.

Posted: May 17, 2013
												One of those Indie games with a not-so-indie look to it. Its an amazing game, despite theres people crying about the "Counter-intuitive" controls for the Xbox 360 controller, where you use the Right Trigger for Primary Fire, Right button for Secondary Fire, Left trigger for Faster Throttle, Left button for Break. Theres someone out there who wants the Sholder buttons to be Bank left/right. but dont take in consideration of where other controls map to. The controls are tight and pretty easy to learn, the difficulty keeps you on your toes, and the immersion can only be enhanced more than it already is, with its upcoming support for the Oculus Rift. The soundtrack is great (though i wish it would be a bit more upbeat, otherwise, no complaints), the visuals are amazing, and its a Freespace Shooter/Space Flight Sim. What more could you ask for.

When you complete a mission, the game shows you your score and gives you a medal, a new weapon and an upgrade if you have completed the challenge. Posted: August 14, 2015
												If you’re a space games veteran, you’ll find some things in this game that were taken from other space games. For example, you’ll see the large torpedoes and “no need to dodge” countermeasures from “Starlancer”, you’ll remember the flak cannons and ship beams from “Freespace 2”, and you’ll find a Karan S’jet clone. I believe even the missile types are copied from “FS 2”.What distinguishes this game from the others of its kind is the ability to turn into a mech and fire spread missiles at multiple targets. If you’re a fan of mecha anime, this will be pretty familiar to you. It takes some time to get used to this system. However, once you master it, you’ll be fighting like a real “Macross/Robotech” ace, transforming between mech and fighter in the middle of dogfights.You should be warned that this game is also more arcade-like than usual. No power management, no radar, no shield convergence. When you fly a bomber, you have an infinite amount of torpedoes. When you restart from a checkpoint, you get a full ammo reload and hull repair.The story is pretty basic. Colonials want to destroy Earth and that’s all you know about them. There’s nothing about their ideology or personality. There’s no communications from them whatsoever throughout the game, not even a “Surrender or die!”. Enemy units don’t have names, not even the cruisers and carriers.Mission design is the game’s biggest flaw. When you’re attacking enemy fighters and your flight leader says “ignore the fighters, focus on your objectives”, what she means is “enemy fighters have infinite waves, so don’t bother”. Sometimes you have to take out flak cannons before the bombers come in, sometimes you don’t. Sometimes the objective is to destroy the cruiser, sometimes you have to protect the bombers which will do that for you and it’s mission failed if they get destroyed by those infinite waves of enemy fighters. You’ll see so many enemy ships throughout the campaign, that you’ll wonder if Earth ever had a chance to win the war in the first place. On defense missions, you’ll learn to love checkpoints.It’s a fun game. Looks easy at first and it only gets hard when you start fighting the Black Fleet. When you master the strike suit, you’ll love flying it. However, if you played classics like “FS 2” and the X-wing or “Wing Commander” series, it’s likely that you won’t take this game seriously.For example, when I did the bomber mission and realized I had infinite torpedoes plus a ton of missiles for self-defense, I remembered my experience as a TIE Bomber pilot and the bomber tutorial in “FS 2” and I actually laughed.

												What we have: a space combat game. Do we have much space combat games: No.So go ahead and buy the game, if you like genre.The last space simulation game that I played was the Freelancer. (That's nearly 10 years ago.) Well, this game is not a "simulation". We have a pure space combat game here, which will take about 7 to 10 hours to complete. If you want to achieve all the upgrades, then it will probably take more than 20 hours. Battles are solid in this game. Period. Tons of allied and enemy crafts flying around you, explosions, plasmas, beams, all together mixed with beautiful space backgrounds. And you feel like you are controlling a space craft, not a weightless camera. Soundtrack is also surprisingly good and though the story is cliche, it gives a good taste for an arcade game.But don't except Freespace or Freelancer. S.S.Z is clearly a low-budget game than those and focuses only on combat. The ship designs, including the Strike Suit are ugly. Some missions are clearly interesting but somes are very repetitive and so on...You may like the space genre. The last space game you played may be about 10 years old. Maybe you are dying for Star Citizen and want a popcorn along the long way. This game is worth of your money.7.5/10

Posted: May 22, 2013
												It's a shame we live in a world where a 65 rating is considered bad and not just average. In light of this, screw Metacritic.SSZ is a straightforward, arcadey space combat game with a twist. Being able to transform into what's essentially a Gundam is a great spin on the genre, and you get a real sense of power when you do; casually swatting away swarms of enemy fighters and missiles like they were nothing. Yet it balances this power with an energy bar of sorts, the more enemies you destroy, the more the it charges, making you swap between the two forms often, which keeps the pace of the action high and stops it from degenerating into constant dogfights.Strike Suit Zero is a pure fun. If you like streamlined, action oriented space games, this is easily one of your best options available. It's a simple beast, but it's also a fast paced, satisfying, and damn good looking game.

Posted: December 12, 2013
												Strike Suit Zero is a love letter to your nerdy, nerdy childhood - a time when it was reasonable to buy several $200 flightsticks and throttles just to pretend you were flying around space, chasing bandits down and wondering just what made that strange backdrop of exploding stars happen. The combat is quick, making it feel very arcade-like most of the time but there is still plenty of room for tactics, which become necessary to master towards the game's ending. The story element is presented through decent dialogue, but I never felt that i was really into it for that, this game is for those that love dazzling fireworks in a free moving environment, and not for those that get motion sickness at all. Definitely one for the couch, too - the trails of your missles create an atmosphere unto themselves that is at once exciting and zen-like to behold.If you can handle the anime-touched sensibilities inherent in the ship & character designs, and the idea of a transforming ship makes you smile, you'll have a good time with SSZ, worth the asking price for those who've missed good space shooting for the past decade (and a no brainer for everyone else when on sale).

Posted: January 3, 2014
												Strike Suit Zero is one of the best space simulators to come along for a long time, and is comparable to Freelancer, Homeworld and O.R.B. in terms of enjoyability. While it has striking similarities with Project Sylpheed, it concentrates more on action, fighter-to-fighter dogfights, and smaller realistically-powerful weapon loadouts. The story is somewhat watery, but is a tried and true plot; the interactions with Control (and the A.I. 2.0) are amusing and probably simulate true intelligent and powerful A.I. There is a wide variety of settings for playing the game, and even the mouse and keyboard (for me) worked wonderfully. I would give this a 9, 9.5 maybe out of 10, and would recommend buying this, especially if you can get it on sale, to any lover of space games that aren`t strategy.

Posted: November 9, 2013
												In the nineties space combat was a thing of the present and many series became part of gaming history. Then history apparently decided to move on and the genre has been lain dormant for years. Strike Suit Zero is the debut from indie studio Born Ready Games and gives ample reason for both nostalgia and anticipation.Developers have clearly studied the genre classics but I did not see Strike Suit Zero as mere retro but rather as classicism. All the lessons learned from the past are condensed into a clear, timeless form. There is no extra weight anywhere. No side paths are taken nor excess features added. You can shake and batter the game all you want but nothing will come loose.This principle extends to the writing as well for there is no characterization and virtually no lore. I enjoyed being spared expositions and lore dumps but on the other hand missed the sense of history or touches of everyday life. The game world is elegant and pure but cold, almost metallic, and this will not appeal to everyone.There are thirteen missions in the campaign and most of the criticism towards the game have been directed at the level of difficulty. It has to be said that many missions required complete restarts and in some cases replaying earlier missions for missed upgrades. Whether or not this is a bad thing is up for debate. I enjoyed the challenge and the general mission design where things escalated in a logical fashion. There are typically two checkpoints per mission and restarting from one will restore both hull and ammunition which makes things more manageable. The titular Strike Suit is powerful to say the least but requires skill to master. The missions are so intense and tightly knit that a precise execution of the objectives is always required.For a Kickstarter title I was continually stunned by what I saw and heard. The soundtrack is the equal of any recent sci-fi game and was composed by Paul Ruskay of Homeworld fame. Even better are the fantastic visuals. Seeing the screen lit up by capital ships' beam cannons and dozens of fighters and bombers fighting for survival is spectacular to say the least. The potential for screenshots is great indeed, especially given the various backdrops ranging from misty nebulas to a destroyed planet. Voice actors sound calm and clear throughout and fit the atmosphere admirably. Developers clearly believe in their work and have been very active with the community, posting on the Forums, adding free mod tools and patching as needed. Given the fact no one can jump out of themself and think as a bodiless ghost objectivity is a hard thing to achieve. Accordingly I cannot say how Strike Suit Zero would feel for those unfamiliar with the genre. On one hand the game almost expected that I already knew space combat beforehand. Weapon and targeting systems seemed familiar and so did the process of supporting capital ships in major engagements, et cetera. On the other hand there are no serious post-millennial competitors out there at the moment. Strike Suit Zero is like space in more ways than one: cold but beautiful in a way that appealed to my personal tastes very much indeed and will more than likely do the same for anyone wanting to embrace the void for the duration of this gaming experience.

Posted: June 13, 2016
												Quick Summary: Strike Suit Zero is like a slightly inferior version of Freespace 2, but still a good game. You also have the option of transforming into an♥♥♥♥♥kicking space robot, so that’s a plus.About 300 years in the future, mankind receives a signal containing instructions on space travel, leading to a glorious age of exploration and colonization. Of course nothing good lasts and the Colonies eventually want independence from the United Nations of Earth (UNE). Things come to a head with the discovery of alien technology that massively tips the scales in favor of the Colonies. Too bad you play a pilot for the UNE so you’ve got your work cut out for you.Strike Suit Zero starts off as a space fighter simulator game very similar to Freespace, but with less weapon and ship customization and you’re not the “squad leader” so you can’t order your teammates around or call for support. Your ship has guns and missiles for weapons, and shields + EMP for defense. The EMP is like a flare that you fire off right before a missile hits you to deflect it. Some of your missiles have lock-on capability and are good against fighter craft, while others may be dumb fire and be good for hitting large slow capital ships. Yes, the capital ships have turrets and weak points that you can destroy to keep them from chewing up you and your teammates. A few levels into the game you gain access to the Strike Suit, a prototype fighter with the ability to transform into a humanoid robot with superior weapons after gathering enough “flux.” You gain flux from killing fighters or shooting turrets off of the larger enemies. Think of it as a kind of hyper meter that you constantly gain and spend by transforming into the strike suit and firing your weapons. In strike mode your main gun becomes like a flak cannon (moderate damage but auto-aiming) and your missile weapon becomes a super-fast lock-on homing missile that can acquire large numbers of targets before firing (with infinite ammo). Basically if you have to wipe out waves of enemy fighters, switch to strike suit mode and just spray them dead.Pros:+I like space fighter games where you fight large enemies mounted with large numbers of destructible turrets. With patience and accuracy your fighter can take down corvettes, frigates, cruisers, and even carriers.+Some nice music to blast your enemies to.Cons:-The story is mediocre-You need to have the game’s DLC to get about half of the game’s steam achievements.Overall the game is fun and actually less difficult that it seems. I played Strike Suit Infinity first and got my♥♥♥♥♥kicked. I should have started with Strike Suit Zero since this game actually has a story and slowly ramps up the difficulty.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												A good old-school arcade/action space shooter. Non-stop action, explosions and very little plot in-between them; do not expect a complex backstory, or an open-world game like Freelancer or the X series! Just blow up your enemies wave after wave and then fly to the next waypoint/mission!PROs- very good visuals- system requirements are not demanding- good soundtrack- non-stop action- you fly a FREAKIN' TRANSFORMING MECHA WHICH SPAMS 40 MISSILES AT TIME- some missions are quite challenging, even for a veteran (which is a good thing in 2014)CONs- clumsy targeting controls (for fighter mode), targeting then becomes irrelevant in Strike Suit / Macross Missile Massacre mode- once you master the Strike Suit, it becomes a mindless slaughter- it is quite a short game (took me 10 hours to complete the main campaign and to unlock all the upgrades/titanium medals)- to add a few hours of gameplay you have to buy the Heroes of the Fleet DLC, which is another 6€ if not on sale- upgrades unlock in some missions requires you to actually replay such mission many times only to avoid the death of a certain non vital allied ship or to kill an Heavy Cruiser with a light figher... Definitively not fun

Non-stop action, explosions and very little plot in-between them; do not expect a complex backstory, or an open-world game like Freelancer or the X series! Just blow up your enemies wave after wave and then fly to the next waypoint/mission!PROs- very good visuals- system requirements are not demanding- good soundtrack- non-stop action- you fly a FREAKIN' TRANSFORMING MECHA WHICH SPAMS 40 MISSILES AT TIME- some missions are quite challenging, even for a veteran (which is a good thing in 2014)CONs- clumsy targeting controls (for fighter mode), targeting then becomes irrelevant in Strike Suit / Macross Missile Massacre mode- once you master the Strike Suit, it becomes a mindless slaughter- it is quite a short game (took me 10 hours to complete the main campaign and to unlock all the upgrades/titanium medals)- to add a few hours of gameplay you have to buy the Heroes of the Fleet DLC, which is another 6€ if not on sale- upgrades unlock in some missions requires you to actually replay such mission many times only to avoid the death of a certain non vital allied ship or to kill an Heavy Cruiser with a light figher... Definitively not fun

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Buying this game was somewhat of a gamble to me.At first I only wanted to play some space sim because I missed Freelancer, and I got disappointed quickly because apparently SSZ is not an open world game. It's more of an arcade/action game, with level-based progression. However, just because it's not open world doesn't mean it's a bad game. In fact, it's really cool!Gameplay is fast, control is so smooth and works well both with mouse-keyboard or gamepad (I prefer gamepad though). Cockpit view is nice, and the graphics are good enough albeit nothing special. The difficulty is a bit high at times, especially if you want to get the Optional Objectives. Once you've unlocked the Strike Suit, the gameplay changes DRAMMATICALLY. It feels so empowering, so great to be liberated from the normal movement of a spaceship.The soundtrack is also pretty good, especially when it includes vocal track by KOKIA (one of my most favorite Japanese singers).  You can get the Strike Suit Zero Mega Bundle cheap these days, so I recommend you buy the bundle altogether. It's a fun game!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												This game is OK.  The redeeming aspect of it is the gameplay, which is as good as you can find right now for a space sim.  It's fun and engaging, and both fighter and strike suit modes offer different forms of gameplay gratification.  The graphics are pretty good (with exception to their implementation of intergalactic warp speed which is just a tacky visual distortion effect).  Production value on this game is quite limited, but this is an indie game from a small studio with more limited resources, so I can overlook things like poor voice acting and purely text-based mission briefs.  The video demonstrations of your weapon options from the loadout screen is a nice touch though.Unfortunately, the story is worthless.  It's completely unengaging and doesn't do anything to build out any of the personalities the game tries to expose you to.  The plot and characters are all derivatives of implementations from classic games from this genre, but here they're combined into a rather formless blob that fails to really compel you to care about anything going on in the game's universe.  The missions are all artificially longer than they need to be, and only support checkpoints.  The difficulty is inconsistent from mission to mission, and the controls have a rather substantial learning curve due to them not using any previously established standard for flight controls in favor of developing one of their own.  Team AI also seems to be lacking and all too often it's up to you to destroy the overwhelming majority of enemies in order to ensure mission objectives are completed.  As a game that was inspired by the likes of the Elite series and Freelancer among others, the fact that this game has an exclusively linear mission schedule is a bit disappointing as well.  While overall SSZ has more bad things going on than good ones, by playing the game you actually spend more time engaged with what works in the game than what doesn't.  I feel an apt comparison for this game would be Square's Project Sylpheed, which has nearly identical flaws, but substantially worse flight mechanics.  SSZ would be best described as a better version of that game.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Strike Suit Zero is excellent, though to reach it's full potential I find that a controller or joystick is best.The combat is it's strength. Combat is SSZ is fun, first and foremost. The game does an excellent job of providing a degree of power fantasy while still giving a good challenge.Graphics are phenomenal. It's a cinematic game to say the least. Not all the designs are the most original (the main fighter looks like a Terran Sabre from X3:TC), but I didn't notice anything deliberately stolen, and there's nice variety.The plot is mostly a device for getting from one place to one place where you feel like a badass or get your♥♥♥♥♥♥wrecked to another place where you do more of the same.I would note, the Director's edition fixed my main complaint of *giving* me the shiny new death machine, but then not letting me *use* it half the time.In any case, I enjoyed the game thoroughly. I recommend the DLC as well.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												Strike Suit Zero (SSZ) is a frustatingly beautiful game; the personification of a game with excellent gameplay marred by horrible enemy variation and an outlandish story. You are a pilot of a fleet taking off to exterminate an alien threat. The game's namesake ship however isn't even obtainable until the third mission - and even then you are charged with taking other ships such as the interceptor (a variation on the starting ship) and a bomber (which was actually pretty cool to operate). The aspect of the game that makes it most difficult is the combat: I want frentic warfare - not a jumbled mess. The dogfights are engaging if only for a moment; taking down capitol ships is an exercise in bullet/missle-sponges; and using the strike suit is like drunkingly blasting ships. Plus it leaves you more vulnerable to attacks - which makes no sense because you have to garner flux to use it and equipping (transforming) the suit should make you more of a bad♥♥♥♥♥ Instead it makes you a sitting duck that relies on wobbly shooting (granted, lock-on firing is available). The story actually has a good conclusion but everything before it is wonky. At some random point there is a grand coupe de tat that is massively overlooked because you are too busy trying to master the controls to even pay attention to the dialogue.The game's greatest weakness is that it doesn't flaunt the suit! Let me free fly with this piece of machinery. Make it more controllable. Make it worth garnering flux! Sadly, the game falls flat for me, and beating it was a months-long mission whose only vincidation of knocking off one more game off my protruberent Steam library.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												So let me begin by saying: If you enjoyed the space combat in "Freelancer" you'll probably slide right into this without a hitch.I did enjoy freelancer a lot, but the combat wasn't the only thing in the game. So that's where the similarities end. Strike Suit Zero is entirely combat missions. That's it.Shoot the baddies in space, fulfill the requirements and get an upgrade to your ship's stats (which really don't seem that noticable, max ranked shields feel about as sturdy as rank 1) and as you check off missions in the list you will get new weapons.There really isn't any customization, and upgrades aren't that big a deal. Some "upgrades" come with a cost, such as using up more energy for a better gun... but you can't really upgrade your energy -on demand- so you're going to choke after firing 5 or six shots.You have about four ships to choose from barring the purchase of any DLC (Strike suit- is butts outside of strike mode, Fighter- basic ship, more boolets/missiles than strike suit's basic mode, Interceptor - a little mosquito, Bomber - infinite slow as dirt torpedos, fires ping pong balls for bullets, decent amt of missiles)The eponymous "Strike Suit" only becomes available after three missions of flying a basic little fighter craft around, and comes with it's own kind of annoying mechanic: a "Flux energy" bar, which is powered up by blowing crap up, You can then expend this flux energy to go into Strike mode: a robot suit, instead of pursuit mode which is your base crappy ship which has less armaments than the starter fighter ship. Strike mode lets you actually start killing things and operates like a dream. Really they should give you some kind of option to play with an infinite flux bar, because the strike suit is basically where all the fun lives. You can instantly track targets with a press of a button, you fire cool dancing missiles that wreck enemies, and you can -STOP MOVING- which is probably the MOST IMPORTANT PART OF STRIKE MODE. If i could put my ship engines on full stop the way strike mode can hold position, I WOULD.Strafing runs are crap, but all the ships except the strike-moded, flux using strikesuit, are forced to do strafing runs and it is garbage. In Freelancer you could -gasp- STOP YOUR SHIP and sit there FIRING AT THINGS. It even comes with it's own built in downside so you don't need to balance it with "stop fuel" or something ridiculous, because YES you're a sitting duck BUT you can focus fire those annoying stationary battlecruiser turrets and such.There are a LOT of stationary targets you're expected to either burn all your flux energy on or do a zillion strafing runs at.Graphically it FEELS like everything is at 1/2 scale. Like I'm playing with minatures or something. enemy ship models could stand to be increased in size by about 1.5x to 2x.Really if there was a way to use points from missions to upgrade my ships further (add more guns to the underpowered pursuit mode of the strike suit) a button to mash for -FULL STOP- on any ship so you could sit and fire like a turret at a stationary target, and a few more weapon options (energy missiles, some kind of missile without ammo aside from flux) this might just scratch all my space ship itches. Is the tagline "Space combat reborn" accurate? No, it's freelancer style space combat without some of the key moves (cut engines & drift, stop) and without any real customization (you get a energy gun, a machine gun, and pick a missile type.)As it stands, Strike suit zero isn't a bad game for what it is: a short space combat mission-y romp.Is it worth the current asking price of 20 bucks? Ehhh... Get it on sale/bundled or something, there's not that many missions.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												I'm confused by all the good reviews for this game. Sure, the graphics look nice, but the controls! Oh, the controls! I got fed up right after the initial training segment.I tried using an Xbox 360 controller as well as keyboard and mouse and, even with customizations, I couldn't get comfortable. The problem is that the left\right movement doesn't behave like you'd expect. You would expect the you'd go left when pressing left and right when pressing right, but your ship goes into more of a barrel roll which leaves you upside down and completely disoriented. I know this is in outer space so it won't control like, say, StarFox, but I have to believe there was a better way to do these controls than this.If you are willing to suffer through this, or somehow manage to get comfortable with the controls, then I'm sure you could have fun. If you are looking for a good shooter that you can jump into and start having fun, look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Interesting story, good graphic, simple controls and dynamic action. It's game you want to play. Game offers you dynamic action where you are in the middle of war. Start by dueling mere fighters, you may end as pilot of bomber sending torpedo package for Carrier or Space Station. Missions are interesting - starting by reconnaissance through cutting enemy supplies to full scale attack shipyards. Our machines can be upgraded but to get these upgrades, you need to meet specific conditions what may require to search different method to complete previously completed scenarios. Try game yourself, you shouldn't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Strike Suit Zero has strength in its guns, but none in its voice.The story is about as compelling as piece of cold chicken. There's no effort in building any kind of drive outside of 'there's the bad guys and their ships are red, kill 'em.'Guns shoot and kills as they should, that's their job after all. The idea of a gundam starfighter just blows me away, this is the most fun I've had in an aircraft game.The later levels are obnoxiously long, and there are no save game slots for during missions. Either you beat the level and wait ten minutes for the next one to start, or you die and wait five minutes for the level to restart.This game is broken in comparision to Strike Suit Infinity, Zero being not worth the effort to beat. 5 out of 10 stars

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												If you watch the trailer, and stopped for a second to think "wow this game looks pretty good" you should stop right there and buy it. Personally, its brilliant - combat is fast and frantic, dogfights against impossible odds have you diving, rolling, and charging - guns blazing - around the map. Thats not to say combat is easy. There are moments when piloting elegantly and unleashing the variety of weapons in your arsenal becomes extremely difficult - and this is completely forgetting about the ability to rapid transform into a flying combat mech that can wipe out entire fleets with missile barrages and cannon fire while dodging incoming missiles.Cons of the game? No free play, just campaign. Lack of enemy units. Enemy units prefer to use swarm tactics to beat you - individual fighters have no combat skill. But the pros of the game outweigh its cons by far. Get the game, if you like games like this.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Я люблю космосимы. Люблю и аркадные и не очень. Но это полная хрень. Скриптовая мыльная опера с картонными персонажами-клише и стандартным героическим сюжетом "плохие напали на хороших и почти убили их, но почему-то не добили, и хорошие начинают ногебать, хотя почему-то только что сливали". Игровой процесс сводится к переключению на ближайшую цель/торпеду и стрельбу в "точку гарантированного попадания". Единственное, что реально круто - саундтрек. Это по большому счёту единственное, за что игру можно купить. Играть при этом не обязательно.I love space simulators both arcade and sim, but this one is total rubbish. Standart fancy graphics, standart prescripted missions, standart "good vs evil" plot, and standart console action "switch to nearest enemy-fire till it blows up-repeat" game process. The one and only real bright side of this game - gorgeous soundtrack. It worth to wait for a sale and buy with soundtrack DLC. Playing isn't necessary.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												So... it's a starfighter that transforms into a Gundam suit. Spaceship shaped like a person is still the dumbest idea ever (yes, even dumber than the double-decker couch). In addition to being a stupid idea (seriously; why does a spaceship need legs? They don't do anything), it's poorly executed.The first three missions of SSZ are solid. Great game. It's freelancer with a bit of a facelift and no trading business to distract from the action. Then you actually get the Strike Suit and the game becomes unbearable. On top of the absolutely useless targeting system, the redundant (and pointless) HUD elements and lack of control customization, controlling this thing is just an absolute mess.Yes, they finally patched-in the ability to re-map the controls but not all of them. Dodge is still hard-bound to "double-tap a movement key." So when I have all my movement bound to proper control axes, dodge is physically impossible. I can't "double-tap" my flightstick to the left. Also: the Strike Suit can't roll.Bottom line: consolized beyond playability. Not a PC game. Absolutely do not buy. Whatever you want this to be, you probably want it to have the basic requirements of playable one expects in a PC game, which it doesn't have.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Strike Suit Zero seems like a good game. It has pretty backdrops, some fun and exciting music, and the promise of a robotic mech spaceship to annihilate enemies. But the gameplay is so frustrating that playing it is a chore, and a frustrating one at that.The basics combat system is good enough. It's fairly easy to get the hang of picking off enemies and sending missiles in every direction. In fact, Strike Suit Zero feels the best when it has you fighting against dozens of enemy fighters, honing in on enemies to build up to the moment where you can transform and unleash hell. But that's a small part of the game. At least 50% of the game is attacking larger stationary ships, taking out cargo, or blowing up turrets, all of which is so boring or frustrating that it brings down the little bit of fun the dogfights provide. To make matters worse, there is a constant barrage of turrets, cannons, and other non-evadable damage that not only steadily drains health but keeps the screen in a disorienting panic that's less exhilirating than it is confusing. Many missions, especially the incredibly tedious ones that involve picking off every turret from a large cruiser, turned into me going for an attack, then flying aimlessly while my shield recharged before trying again. Rinse lather repeat.If you're looking for your fill of space dogfighting, I don't think Strike Suit Zero is your best bet. There are many older games, and even some very recent ones that are starting to fill that hole better. If you're dedicated to playing every space game out there, you'll probably have fun with it, but otherwise I'd sit this one out.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												This game feels like a generic space shooter. It is like Freelancer except that you can't go wherever you want, and you can't take the missions you want. I was looking forward to using the strike suit, but that is also disappointing. In strike suit mode all you get is more damage to your normal guns, missile spamming abilities, auto-aim (if you want it), and the ability to dodge incoming attacks. Dodging in strike suit mode actually seems less effective against missiles than using the deflect ability in normal flight mode :(.  Strike suit mode also runs out very quickly when you try to use a lot of missiles, and then you are just back to normal flight mode. Most of the levels are just fighting waves of enemies and blowing up large carrier space ships, which gets old fast. The final level feels like it is trying to be more like Star Fox and it doesn’t work out. There are no enemies, and you just navigate through tight corridors. This game isn’t worth your money.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												A space dogfighting game with arcade levels of fun.  Unique to this one is the ability to use Strike Mode -- temporarily transforming your fighter into a powerful mech capable of free three-dimensional movement.  This game is fast-paced, but encourages a strategic approach to combat and completing mission objectives, switching between Strike Mode and the standard fighter as is appropriate for the task at hand, managing energy efficiently to maximize Strike Mode's effectiveness, and targeting weak points and weapons to cripple enemy ships while defending your own.It's a great game, lots of fun, and surprisingly intellectually engaging as well.Totes recommend.10/10, would mech again.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Ok I've been playing this for the better part of an hour and I have to say I kinda want my money back even though it was on sale . Dont get me wrong love the games that it gets it inspiration from HomeWorld(come on Homeworld 3), Freelancer, Gundum,.etc, but for me the conrols are very sensitive even when turned all the way down. I could never really get a clean shot on any of the enemies. It felt like i was just getting lucky and destroying stuff becuse the computer decided to fly in a straight line to give me a shot. The mouse should not have been used to steer the ship if you move the mouse too far it will fling you in a hard turn that is hard to come out of. Its almost like the made it so you would have to buy a game pad, but i dont want to have to go out and get one of those just to enjoy this game. A and D only roll the ship i would like to change it so that it turned the ship and the mouse just controled the orientation of the targeting recticle. The game is very good looking from what I have been playing so far it reminds me of Zone of the Enders but just a tad bit slower. Visually it is spot on good explosions if you just happen to be a little to close the the ship that is being destroyed than they are a little too bright. Some of the background elements are great some of them i want to have as a background on my desktop. For now i am going to uninstall it I may get a flight stick to play it properly becsuse it is a little wierd with a mouse and keyboard. So I recommend it if you have a flight stick if you dont and still want to give it a go then i recommend putting the mouse sensativity on low settings that way you will be able to keep up with your enemies in the game and you wont zip past them. And with a flight stick im expecting this to be like Ace Combat.

												Amazing, beautiful, and breathtaking.  No pretend banking or complicated controls, just fun glorious space combat with a good storyline and incredible atmosphere.  The music has a mystic ambience and has good build and intensity to match the story.  The learning curve is quick if you are comfortable with space combat games.  Dont expect RPG type leveling or detailed ship building, the leveling system is simple.  I like the ability to choose cockpit view for immersion.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												If you love Macross, Gundam, or other mecha related nostalgia, then you'll find yourself falling in love with this game. Wonderful art & design, as well as a pleaseing sound track are more than enough reasons to get this game. Of course, it is rather difficult to enjoy those parts of the game because you'll find yourself failing that one mission over, and over, and over again. Yes, the learning curve for this game is rather steep. The controls and the gameplay feel like what it would be if Ace Combat and Armored Core had a baby. But much like Ace Combat and Armored Core, once you get used to the controls, this game finally offers the experience of what it feels like to be a main character from your nostalgic mecha anime. Unless you're me, in which case you'll still feel like a grunt in this really good mecha..

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												The first 5 levels leave you in some largely undesigned fighter ships that are purely there to juxtapose the power of the titular vehicle, the Strike Suit. A mission at the most would have done as you grind through these initial taste testing stages, recieving increasingly bitter doses of the non-newtonian flight model & utterly insufferable tutorial/introductory stages that will put many people off the rest of what eventually transforms into a robust space paint-select-missile-em-up.Despite these minor flaws, Strike Suit Zero still manages to pull through as an enjoyable few hours experience, and the incentive to top the leaderboards could keep the more neckbearded space pilots hooked for longer.8/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												A solid arcade style space combat simulator with respectable graphics, great gameplay, and a great soundtrack.  If you're a fan of space combat flight simulators and a fan of mecha, this will be your cup of tea.  If you're looking for the hardcore, unbridled space fighter simulations of old reborn, this isn't quite there, but it's a good start to revitalize interest in the genre.  Still, this game is fun and presents a fair challenge.Controls are responsive and defaults are well planned out for keyboard/mouse users.  A few different classes of fighters, each with a customizable loadout of weapons you unlock as the game progresses are available, though most of the non strike-suit ones are one offs for particular missions (but they are selectable in others once you complete the mission in question.)  Going into strike suit mode is very reminicent of classic mecha anime where you can heavily damage or eradicate many of your enemies in one fell swoop if you're good enough, a bonus for mecha anime fans of series such as Gundam and Robotech.It's fairly short, but for the price, it's a good experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												really cool space war game. The mecha action is there but very limited bursts like around 10 seconds until you are out of flux and then you have to be in ship mode for the other 95% of the game. I guess they do that because in mech mode you are extremely powerful and can easily wipe out half the guns on a cruiser or take out corvettes with ease while side stepping gunfire. But don't let the beautiful space scenery fool you though, you will hardly have any time to enjoy it and only during the beginning of the mission. Within seconds you'll be under heavy fire from fighters and warships and you do your best to stay alive while trying to attack. But if you do want beautiful scenery while cruising space then SSZ isn't for you. There is no cruise control! only full on attack!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												I'm veeeeery mixed about this game. I love its combat and the fact you feel as though the fights you are fighting are of something bigger in the level. You aren't the main focus. The ship design is awesome and the various weaponry are amazing. The one big flaw with this game, and I cannot stress tis enough, is its controls. It is very difficult to play this game with keyboard and mouse. Where does tis shine? The last level!Strike Suit Zero is an amazing open space dogfighting game. There is no denying this. However, when the last level takes EVERYTHING you have been doing in the former 12 levels (The very open space for movement and maneuvers) and throws it away. Instead, you get one of those precision and closed space levels where your ship is carefully navigating the relics NARROW, LINEAR spaces. Not the open place you have been fighting for all of the game. I would not have minded this if the controls were changed... But they aren't. You play as though you are in that open space. The controls are still either super touchy or not touchy enough in this level.It simply bad level design. Adding to this is the fact you have 10 MINUTES to complete the level. It sounds like enough, right? Not in this level. The corridors are long and the time getting to the core takes up about half the allotted time, more if you are trying to be careful. Bumping the walls WILL immediately drain your shields. You will die a lot. If this level were different, I would have loved every aspect of this game. However, I cannot beat the last level because everything I did in the former levels meant nothing. This game demanded precision in a game where it is not necesary.If you want to get this game, I recommend you do it... If it's on sale. If you are on PC, I would recommend Strike Suit Infinity if you want a fun game like this one, but without the story.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												I've only got a few hours on record, and only made it to the fourth mission. Considering I got this on sale for $5 I'm as happy as could be! This is the first space combat sim I've found that feels really authentic, where aggressive posturing, liberal use of secondaries, and strong piloting skills make a real difference. Getting your first mech is friggin awesome, though it is difficult to control.Controls for the game have me a little worried. I'm using a Kinobo Playstation USB controller that I've mapped for the game specifically. It kinda feels necessary to make it work given the high number of controls you really want to have access to at your fingertips, especially given that the difference between your fighter controls and mech controls is very noticable and you need to be able to move between either without blinking. Mouse and keyboard might be able to make it work, but it feels like a bit of a gamble. Investing in a controler is definitely worthwhile.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												While this isn't a bad game it sure ain't a great one.  Probably my biggest complaint of this game is the gameplay.  It just felt like a slightly improved Battlefront 2 space battles.  Probably the only cool component of gameplay was the Strike Suit (which you dont even get until a hour in).  Another thing that ruined the game for me was the missions.  They were way too long and generic.  It was go kill these invaders...oh look more of them go kill them too.  The story to go along with it was alright but nothing too special.  The graphics were great for an indie game.  The ship graphics were okay, but the backgrounds (space and planets) were awesome.  Probably the best thing about this game was the soundtrack.  I usually don't even think about the soundtrack when playing games but this one was different, its amazing. Too bad the game wasn't on par with the soundtrack.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												This game tries to hard to be the next Zone of the Enders... But falls flat on the execution. While the idea of changing between fighter and suit modes are interesting, it still feels limited on what you can actually do. Enemies are another issue where there are a few types of fighters and then larger ships that you go up against but.. Beyond the corvets going down to suit-mode missiles or just taking a long time doing strafing runs with your normal weapons, the frigate and cruser enemies just have a load of gun hardpoints that don't actualy factor into the enemy ship's health and it takes ages trying to kill them on your own.. Which, while you have NPC help, oftentimes it feels like they're just there to make pretty explosions around you. And remember the cool bosses that ZoE had? Like that giant sphere Zakat! Nothing like that here unless it's at the very last level... Which I honestly can't be bothered with getting past chapter 10 of 13. Honestly, it's a good basis but it doesn't capture the same fast and frenetic feel that you might be looking for as from the ZoE series. On those grounds, I can't reccomend this title

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												At first this looks like a good space fighter sim with some Zone of the Ender mechanics, but man did they ever get it wrong. Whoever did the game balance doesn't know what they're doing. Maybe they used to make board games? I'm not sure. But the regular ship takes forever to build up one volley of shots. This means taking out 20 fighters (a common objective in the first 3 missions) can take about 20 minutes. Why would they do that? Restrictions are fun! Let's restrict everything!Like the Strike Suit. You'd think, "okay, cool robot form that's even in the game title: Of course you should be able to change that whenever you like, right?" Wrong. You have to destroy debris and enemy fighters to 'power it'. How does that even make sense? Shooting in the Strike Suit turns into Motion Blurr City, which is extremely laggy. There's also no lead targets in Strike Suit mode, so good luck hitting anything with primary fire. The suit itself seems terribly underwhelming. Its best attack when you first get it is a volley of missiles. Not very exiting, and doesn't make you feel powerful.The game was advertised when it came out as if this was a successor to the Zone of the Enders series. No. Its just a cheap powerup gimmick in a space sim with a standard engine (think Star Wars: Star Fighter on the PS2, but not as easy to control or as intuitive). The balance is abismal. The story seems interesting, but every time you think a level is going to end you get "wait, we've got 50 more fighters inbound" and it just makes me sigh. I gave up after 10 minutes of the Strike Suit being seeming utterly useless and unable to kill even one turret on an enemy frigate.Maybe I'll come back to it one day and find out something I missed, but man does this game make me want to cry. Look at my name. How disappointed do you think I am?

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Everything about this game just misses the mark for me.. Graphics, gameplay and the controls in particular. The space combat can be fun however it can get a little tedious and frustrating (for me in particular, being an angry gamer) at times.. All these problems all just combine for an average space combat sim in my opinion. Also the game itself honestly is not good enough to be compared to other games of its genre specifically in ways of visual appeal/graphics, after all isn't space meant to be a "beautiful enigma"?.. e.g Star Conflict is free to play (although some things must be payed for) however the controls and visuals are far superior than SSZ and for me (Star Conflict) "destroys" SSZ in the field of which SSZ professes to be the best at: Combat.. Strike Suit Zero has a good story and can be entertaining at points however those are the only positives I can state about this game.. If you are to get this game.. get it on sale.. P.S: This is my opinion don't rage at me if I don't have the same viewpoint as you.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2013
												I love flying shooters, from arcade style sideways shooters to planes and everything in between. From all the space shooters I have played this one is the worst. The game looks pretty, has great music, and seems to have a decent story, but the controls and everything in between are terrible. With a controller the flying is on the right thumbstick, Not sure who thought that was a great idea but let that set the stage for the rest of the crap playability. The dialog is so low its practically muted, meaning you need to crawl through setting until you adjust the audio to where you can hear it.  This game is a classic case of how developers build a world but are clueless about making it enjoyable for players, from the audio, to controls, to the junk ship you ship, this game is a waste of space.  Gameplay fatal flaws:Also being a 3D shooter, there is no distance to target over the lockon icon for the enemy you are tracking, and their so small but the icon stays the same size its impossible to tell when their right on top of you.  There is a distance thing with a picture in the lower left but I cant look at that while chasing these  mosquito enemies.The enemies suffer from the syndrome of them flying all over like their hopped on drugs with no pattern or logic to what their doing.  Its like those sniper games where for no reason enemies run back and forth in place while sniping you from across the map with their guns while you with a sniper rifle are helpess. Your ship is soooOOooo slow until you beat the mission and unlock the other ships.  HEY DEVS! how about just making it fun to begin with?  Picture a Volkswagen bug chasing a Ferrari and you get this game. This is a game where there are other ships but you cant access them until you beat a map, which means playing the crap way then later hey you can have fun, no thanks, your game sucks. The nail in the coffin for me was the shooting mechanics, to fire a missle its right bumper meaning you must stop firing your machine guns to fire a missle.  What modern plane would be designed so terribly that only one weapon works at a time, this is the future right, I mean their in space.   Rating: 0/10 Value: $0.00

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												I'm not sure what to say, the game is great until about the third level, where you get switched into a different ship (the strike suit) and pretty much everything you've learned up to that point becomes invalid, and you suddenly have to learn a completely new control system while the enemies only get tougher. What's worse, it seems utterly impotent compared to the previous ship, but perhaps that is only because there is no explanation on how to properly use it?? Its weapons can't even shoot down torpedoes (which typically just go splat), how are you supposed to fight entire enemy fleets?The artwork is beautiful, even if the special effects are a bit half-baked (cutscene hyperspacing?). I wish You could iron-out that spot where the gameplay just stalls and release it as an update, because up to that point it is a very fun game.

Posted: June 1, 2014
												- Gorgeous graphics, awesome soundtrack- Game is mission based, not open-world like Freelancer- Less on flight-sim, more on fast-paced arcade style dogfights (think Freelancer)- You will pilot a spaceship that transforms into a ♥♥♥♥ing robot, complete with Macross-style missile swarms! What more do you want?- I wish Gundam or Macross had a game that plays like this- Premise is nothing new: humans colonized the stars, and the colonials want freedom from Earth government; premise is same with Gundam, Zone of the Enders, and a bunch of other similar settings- Lots of flat one-dimensional characters, although I was too busy owning enemy fleets to be bothered by this- Pretty short game, although I found the whole thing to be sufficient, considering the price- A few bugs here and there, including one crash incident that happened to me: 


Damn I was so close 
A Screenshot of Strike Suit Zero
By: StickyWhiteStuff




- I hope there's gonna be a sequelThoughts on improvements:- Upgrade system is weird. You complete achievement-esque goals per mission to get upgrades (finish mission in 15 minutes or less to get a shield upgrade or something.. what's the context for that?). May have been better using a purchase system (as in, you would earn some sort of credits/resources after every mission and purchase upgrades for your ship).- Controls could do with some simple improvements. For targeting, there's only "target nearest enemy", and "target nearest objective". Later on you will realize that you will need a "target nearest enemy torpedoes" because ♥♥♥♥ those torpedoes.- The cutscenes in the middle of battle takes away your control and shows whatever it wants to show you in some pretty camera angle. This breaks your flow, especially if you were shooting at a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ interceptor when the cutscene triggers. They should implement a picture-in-picture style instead.

Posted: May 30, 2014
												In a word: forgettable.Ship unlocks don't carry forward to new missions, only previous missions - and there's no real reason to replay them.Side objectives - which are your sole source of basic upgrades (armor, shields, etc) - are only gained from completing side objectives, but with no radar, it's hard to pick out side objectives from the swarm of angry arrows swirling around the edge of your screen - nevermind that you must cycle target priorities until what you want pops up. This is especially agonizing as many side objectives are "stop all the torpedoes"; there are no audio or visual warnings for when torpedoes are launched, so unless you are constantly mashing 'F' to see if any are in-flight, you have absolutely no way to tell - and if even one hits, the side objective is failed...but it gets even worse! When you fail a torpedo side objective, you don't even receive a notification - so you don't even know you failed it until you've sunk ~15 - 20 minutes into a mission and see the results screen. On top of that, on every single mission that has a "torpedoes" side objective, you are required to constantly monitor corvettes, capital ships, and fighters - which you cannot really find unless you set your target priority to each in sequence by tapping 'T'...but since there's no warning when torpedoes are fired, you have to constantly cycle target priorities and mash 'F'...and then you find out 20 minutes later when you've cleared the mission (hopefully) that one single torpedo must have snuck past ya - no unlock for you!At one point I was boosting away from an enemy cruiser to let my shields recharge - note that this was a good 14 minutes into a mission - and I was abruptly greeted by a "MISSION FAILED. YOU WENT AWOL. EVERYTHING BLEW UP. EARTH BLEW UP. ALL THE PUPPIES DIED. GAME OVER." screen. There was no warning, no audio or visual queue that I was getting close to the edge of the zone like a better game would do, NO - it just springs a "GAME OVER" on you.Your AI allies are comparitively crippled, dealing significantly less damage and having less hull/shields than enemies. They also pretty much suck at covering you when you're in a slower craft, like the bomber you are required to fly in a few missions.While the ship agility is fine for open space where there aren't really any obstacles, the last stage will have you smashing your face through your screen trying to guide your ship through 9 minutes of obstacles inside a tunnel.Altogether it's not a terrible game, it's just underwhelmingly 'meh'. I plowed through it in probably < 8 hours on normal and do not care to play it any further. The issues mentioned above are pretty darn pervasive and aggravating throughout the course of the campaign.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												Those who grew up watching Japanese mecha-themed anime (like anything out of the Gundam universe) will enjoy this game for it almost-perfectly captures the sense of overwhelming power and superiority one might get when piloting the proverbial weaponized suit. That feature alone can carry this game to a "good" rating from most fans of anime and the space combat genre. Add colorful and vibrant graphics, a wonderful soundtrack, intense gameplay, and scalable difficulty (from "Grandparent-friendly" to "WTF"), then you've got a wonderful reason to give the developers your time and money.

Posted: September 10, 2013
												Strike Suit Zero is quite the entertaining experience. Its graphics and soundtrack are -- forgive me for the pun -- stellar. It feels like you're actually flying through a remote, unexplored section of deep space, giving a sense of near-complete immersion to the game. Although the story is somewhat generic and not all that compelling, to me, it's not the story that matters; it's the fun you have while playing. Some people bash this game for reasons I do not know; I am not one of those people. This game also features Steam Workshop compatibility, allowing you to create your own custom missions! With all that and an awesome space-fighter to boot going for it, why haven't you already bought this game?

The little issues are still there, like having to set my main monitor to 1280x800 but that is do-able for right now.  The game is very nice looking and responds well with the Rift and my joystick. Posted: December 15, 2013
												A game from a tiny developer with a successful kickstarter project, Strike Suit Zero is an accomplishment I'm sure many will remember. What this game lacks in complexity, it more than makes up for elsewhere. If anything, all you can really complain about is that it feels as though there's just not enough of it! So you want to know what this game is, what it does, etc. Well, imagine for one moment if the RTS game Homeworld, was smooshed together with the TV series Battlestar Galactica, the pacing of Super R-Type, the mecha styling of Mobile Suit Gundam, the atmosphere and vibrance of Zone of the Enders and infused with the soul of the X3 series. Now imagine that all of that comes together in an orgy of frenetic 3d-space combat, beautiful, vibrant graphics, a challenging AI, a good selection of ships/mecha and weapons and a soundtrack reminiscent of the musical stylings of Talvin Singh.Bottom Line : If you love your twitch gaming, but also want an atmospheric, challenging, not to mention stunning, 3d space shooter with an engaging story and an AI that'll keep you on your toes, then look no further. This really is a gem, and at under a fiver on steam, you've really got no excuses if this kind of thing is your cup of tea!Overall : 9/10Audio : 9/10Graphics : 9/10Gameplay : 9/10

												This game is a lot like Freespace 1 and 2. Basically, if you took those games and gave them a modern engine, it would be this. The only big difference (so far) is that after a few missions, you get the Strike Suit, which can either fly (when it's in ship mode) or hold relatively still and fight (in robot mode). However, the game (so far) doesn't have some of the stuff I miss from Freespace, like missiles designed to take out specific ship systems. Posted: January 2, 2016
												Strike Suit Zero is one of the best games that I have had the honor of playing. The graphics are great, the story is interesting, the combat is absolutly fantasic and the music. OOOH the music. But without furthur or do here is the review. Overall Rating: 8/10Graphics: The graphics are absolutly fantastic. I don't have to specify why, because if you look at the screen shots, and the trailer you will see why. The effects, and the lights make it feel like your in a fire fight, and the sounds that go along with the graphics are just fantastic. Although since the lights and textures are bright and colorful and they are of abundance so players you are warned.Combat: The combat is the highlight of this game. The combat goes as followed. You move with the W,A,S,D keys and can use the left shift to use thrusters to boost around the battle field. You have two guns, the Primary which is usually fast fireing and powerful that has unlimited ammunition that uses energy (which regenerates over time). Then there is a various amounts of missles in the game that you can use that have their own speical properties and effectivness in situations. Some times in combat you can have your weapons lock on to the enemy, and the bullets will follow them. Mot of the time I find myself using my primary guns, and to use them effectivly you have to arch your aim so that the enemy flys into it. Fortunatly it gives you a place to fire, so you know where you need to shoot (However you need to be close or the circle will not show up). The primary weapon has unlimited ammunition since it uses the energy of the ship, but the LMG's, and various missles have ammunition and can be depleted fast. There are many different ships you can use, and I personally perfer the Strike Suit. You can switch from Mech to ship with the space button and just like regular primary weapon fire, the Strike suit requires power to be used. How do you do that? By blowing things up! All in all the fighting in this game feels "realistic" so to speak and is very fun and challenging. Although the large amount of enemys in the area of combat can be over whelming, it always pays off to be moving, and to not get to close to the main enemy ships until the fighters are taken care of. In that way its tactical and makes me want to stay with my team. Music: The mustic brings a tear to my eyes, as its as epic as it is interesting. Many times I find music repeating but I don't mind that very much as it is quite epic and makes me fight harder and get into the heat of the moment. Pros- MusicGraphicsCombatlight effects and sounds around the areastoryCons-No multiplayerGets repetitiveFinal Opinon: This game is really good. There are some things that didn't live up to my expectations, not much DLC, no multiplayer, not alot of missions, etc. But on the other hand the dlc isn't a need, the multiplayer would be fun but isn't a thing that needs to happen. The missions are long and increse in difficulty as you go on. The combat, music, and graphics are all in my own opinon great. I bought this game today, and played it for 2 hours. No regrets. If you like Mechs, and the Sci-Fi genres this game is worth the $19.99 and is worth picking up to play.

Posted: November 18, 2013
												Well I really enjoyed that, the mouse and keyboard controls worked great and the combat was just the right difficulty. I really enjoyed switching targets and managing the priority of threats as they came up, as well as ensuring I was using the right weapons at the right times... it was a lot to think about whilst in the midst of a space war.. and I must admit it was really engaging. Got me very much in the mood for Freelancer, another game I have never finished, which has similar controls... ableit isn't involving huge capital ships blasting away at one another in an overarching space conflict like SSZ. The graphics and sound are perfect and it's a well put together game. I can't credit it with originality though, the music seemed to be from Homeworld, the way the capital ships duked it out with huge laser beams streaking between them.. really felt like Freespace, the controls seemed to be taken from Freelancer like I've said, the unflappable naval officers seem to be ripped out of Nexus - The jupiter incident and the narrative.... inspired by them all I'd say.Still! A good game and enjoyable, if they do a sequel I'd certainly keep an eye on it and pick it up at the right price.The Heroes of the Fleet is an enjoyable DLC revolving around simulations of key battles, mainly one's that were historically defeats for the Earth forces you pilot for, all of which took place within the main story line however the protagonist wasn't part of them. . I liked the narrative twist and enjoyed the fact they'd even *put* a thread of story throughout 6 stand alone DLC missions. I think that's commendable. These level's are hard and I found my self on the edge of my seat during the last level in particular, fun times.

Posted: December 13, 2013
												Best mech combat simulator/space flight sim since Zone of the Enders. Gameplay is fast and fluid, offering easy of entry and an adequate difficulty curve as the game progresses. The story serves as little more than a backdrop for the absolutely massive space battles, but to be fair, did you really look into this game for a deep and thought provoking story, or just because you wanted to feel like a badass mech pilot? My only complaint is that sometimes tracking the location of your highlighted target can get difficult in the more frenzied encounters since the directional arrow highlighting it's location is the exact same color as all the other high priority target indicators on the HUD, (of which there will be many in later missions). It makes manually prioritizing your targets somewhat annoying, but not game-breaking in any way.

Posted: December 13, 2013
												I was a big Freespace and Starlancer player back when those games were popular. I was also big into Star Fox and its Nintendo 64 counterpart, in addition to an unhealthy addicted to Earthsiege, Starsiege, and the Mechwarrior series. Suffice to say that I love space combat games and sims, and it is a genre that has sadly lacked any real entries over the last decade to speak of. Strike Suit Zero fills that niche very nicely.When I started SSZ and began playing, it took a little bit of time to re-acquire the whole 'flying in space with a mouse and keyboard' feeling, but once I got the hang of it, it felt as natural as ever. The controls are nice and tight and there isn't a lot of slop. The graphics are polished but the animations during cutscenes can be a little janky sometimes. Voice acting is of far better quality than I would have expected - if you think the voiceovers are going to be as bad as, say, X3, you're wrong. Egosoft could take a note from this game. Graphics and style are overall awesome. I love the depth-of-field/blurring effect when boosting through space in cockpit view. My only gripes - the HUD situation sucks. Honestly. I hate that it's a bar at the top of the screen. It's jarring and unnatural; I would have preferred the HUD to be integrated into the cockpit in first-person view and at the sides or bottom of the screen in third-person. My other gripe - and this is going to be kind of an assanine gripe, as it centers around a key concept in the game - is the strike suit. I hate the strike suit. It just feels like a gimmicky, juvenile anime trope. I've never enjoyed mecha anime and I've never enjoyed humanoid mechs. I've always preferred the gritty down-to-earth mechs of later BattleTech and the hercs of the Earthsiege universe, they just seem more probable and more likely to exist. But I guess it's more a matter of taste, really. In gameplay the Strike Suit mode is very helpful and incredibly powerful - you can lock on to an insane number of enemies and launch cluster rockets that obliterate everything, not to mention the big giant plasma shotgun thing that wrecks face. It's definitely fun. It's use is balanced out nicely by flux mechanic, and I have not really felt the game get easier as a result of having the strike suit. The only real gameplay-related gripe that I have about it is that in strike suit mode you are forced into third person view. I hate that.It's a hard game, too. Really hard. It goes easy on you at first, but once you get your first strike suit, all bets are off. In particular the first level that takes place in a nebula is difficult (due to the fact that sensors, radar, and lockon missiles do not work- you have to rely on dumbfire rockets and visual sight). I love difficult and challenging games. The good:- Difficult- Beautiful visuals and style- Interesting concept in the strike suit- Unlockable ships and progression- Variety in space environments keeps things from getting stale- Feels like a natural progression of the space shooter genre- Music is very catchy- Voiceovers aren't half bad- Price- IndieThe bad- HUD design and placement is awkward- Music can be repetitive at times- Strike suit... mainly on aesthetic grounds- Forced third-person view in strike suit mode- Makes you wish for a modern FreespaceThis game gets 4 out of 5 cookies from me! I look forward to the next game these guys put out. I hope they keep this genre alive and renew interest in it.

												The game didn't leave a good impression on me early in, but I stuck through it until mission 12 hoping for it to grab me, and now I'm done with it.  The game just isn't well designed, and mission 12 fully expressed that to me.  The weapons you get are limited in selection throughout the level.  The objectives and things you do rarely change and deviate from a formula they repeat every other level or 2.  It's basically defend X, attack X, or attack turrets on X to then get to attack X afterwards.Worse yet is on larger vehicles you're supposed to destroy you get little in terms of visual or auditory feedback that you're actually doing decent damage yourself, or if it's just your friendly ally ships.  When the objectives change, the game will do a poor job explaining what you actualy need to do, and point out targets that don't remotely matter to actually finishing it.  The game just does nothing remarkeable outside your strike suite can lock on, and let you paint multiple targets to fire a large missile barrage.  Fun for the first few times, but quickly becomes a tedious activity, as you'll use it a bunch to ween down health on ships with inflated HP.

Posted: February 28, 2014
												I thought the days of X-Wing, Wing Commander: Privateer, and Independence War were over. Okay, so it doesn't have anything like the customization of Privateer, the mystery and exploration of I-War, or the hook of the Star Wars universe. It does have great action, spectacular graphics, and white knuckle dog fighting that could go toe-to-toe with the best of them.

Posted: February 4, 2014
												I absolutely love this game. Came into it relatively blindly. Had just done a revisit of some of my older favorites from the Wing Commander series, and was looking to jump into something similar that made use of newer technology, and SSZ happened to be on sale on Steam that day, so I made the purchase without really knowing what I was getting into. Infinitely happy that I did. The controls take a little getting used to, but the game eases you into them by giving you what's essentially a tutorial mission, followed by a few missions that are pretty light on difficulty and present you with basic forms of each fighting scenario, for example squadrons of fighters you have to take down, a capital ship you have to protect, etc. Once you get used to the key placements it's all pretty straightforward in that regard. The graphics are nothing short of spectacular both in their smoothness running and in presentation. I'm playing on a fairly decent, but not cutting edge machine, and I've experienced very few framerate issues, really only dropping slightly when so much is happening on screen that it's more than my brain can process all at once either. The sound and music are just as good, really fitting the atmosphere of the game, helping to enhance the feeling that you're taking part in massive epic space battles. There's also a good amount of replay value added in the form of mission medals and stat upgrade unlocks, that I know have me revisiting mission after mission to try for higher scores and get the unlocks/medals that I want. The only thing even remotely negative that I can say about the game is that it's pretty light on plot. The majority of the plot is communicated through text that you get both in mission briefings and post-mission reports, along with some cutscenes that take place during missions, but at times it's developed so little that I found myself scratching my head when something big happened, feeling like I didn't really know what was going on at all. But at the same time it's really not the emphasis of the game. The fast-paced large scale beautifully rendered space battles in amazingly atmospheric settings is. So basically if you're looking for something really plot heavy, this may not be the game for you, but if you're looking for a straight up space battle simulator and can live without having much of a plot to go along with it then you won't regret the purchase.
