Posted: December 26, 2013
												I remember watching Gundam and Macross Animes growing up and wishing there were video games like those. There have been many but VERY few manage to capture the scale, scope, and heart of those Mecha-Space Operas and as Space Sims died out over the past 10 years I gave up hope of seeing a great Space Opera game. Until I saw Strike Suit Zero during the Flash Sale.Strike Suit Zero isn't a TRUE space sim in the sense but the arcade style it promotes actually meshes well with the Gundam/Macross styles. Swarms of missiles flying everywhere, ships exploding, pilots screaming out death cries as their ships fall apart around them. The action is fast and intense and after babysitting you for ONE mission, SSZ kicks it into overdrive and then into crazy what the hell how do I beat this mode. HUGE thumbs up for SSZ.While I would love to see some version of Multiplayer emerge, the MOD tools are freely available for someone to attempt it, the single player is excellent and the story very thought out. The music sounded familiar to me as I played and as I did more research discovered it was composed by the same guy that did Homeworld. (A FANTASTIC Space Opera RTS in it's own right.)BUY THIS GAME!

Posted: December 12, 2013
												Ideal for space cowboys.  Linear storyline rather than open world, but contrary to some reviews, I relish the frantic action and storytelling of SSZ.  It's such a nice change to have a game with some challenge to it.  The 3rd person view of the ships reminds me of ye olde Battlestar Galactica.  Taking out the gun turrets on the larger cruisers looks impressive.  Trying to get on the tails of your enemy using piloting skills and thrusters requires some perseverence in order to blast them into oblivion.  SSZ runs very well on my modest AMDm gpu.  It gets quite hypnotic at times, certainly not one for epileptics, and the in game audio is atmospheric.  I must admit i'm not one for the combo exploiting SSI sequel, but it's more of the same I suppose.  I think it was also this game that you can actually get skinning mods for several sci-fy favorites for!  7/10 whilst I await Elite.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												I'm really enjoying this game. To put it simple, It's exacly as GUNDAM SEED, just made into a game. You will notice that the captaplut is the same design :PThe missions are a bit light on text content but all is voiced. Although I believe by mission 5 you will be skipping most of them. The plot is also weak, which makes me think they did not put much time into the writing, which for this game, i'm completly fine with.As for the combat, it certainly needs polished. The fight can be caotic and if you are not familiar with your mouse sensativity you will find free aim completly unplayable. The lock on ability also needs more polished when in Striker mode, mostly tied to the free aim feature. Be aware that using the guns(rifle or energy) i did not find any trouble with it.As for striker mode and persuit mode, it feels swift, DIFFERENT(really important) and balance. On Striker Mode(humanoid, GUNDAM FUN) you feel overpowered like you should, you can simple auto target everyone with Shift and gun them, dodge enemy fire, etc. But the limit you have with it, making that fun end a little bit early ends up balancing it and making hardcore a really challenging difficulty (Although i would like more of that mode). Notice that the multiple lock on feature is very bad, u need free aim and won't detect enemies that are there. It fail completly compared to something like Zone of the Ender, so much that you wouldn't use it at all almost. As for persuit mode, It feels different, both on the weapons you use(you have more range of weapons in this mode) and the fact that you can thrust away from situations that might turn way too bad.  Here i didn't had much to complain, it feels like a fighter should feel. The space bar is perfect to change mode btw.Combat is caotic and the camera doesn't help. Then again, i like that part because it feels real, and having both 3rd person and cokpit views is a plus. The targetting system needs a bit polish, but i find the weapon selection limited. All weapons so far feel different and choice does matter, both guns and missles. But Only 2 buttons to cycle through either guns or missiles isn't enough. I would like to bind my weapons to 1-5 or similar and change them that way.As for the UI, I don't actually like it, but it does the job. I would change many things, but those that I feel that pass personal preference and became somewhat damaging to the player are the fact that your weapons are display through text. Each should have a little image, a machine gun and a rail gun, a Rocket and a Seeker missile, for exemple, that would allow quick recognition of the weapon selected. This doesn't affect guns too much(your aim changes acordingly) but the missile selection is harder than it needs to be.Lastly, regarding the aim i would like to see priority targets more distiguish. The game targetting is somewhat good, but it 3D icons suffer from the same problem games like BF4 and others. Its hard to target exacly what u want quickly or while dealing with an interceptor or changing targets.To Conclude, I found this game alot of fun. The gameplay is fast, challenging and each feature feels different. Although there are not that many types of targets(don't expect 5 types of inteceptors, 10 types of carriers, like in ZotE), the missions are sufficiently different and the form you tackle a interceptor squad, or a carrier or a full on base with carriers and squads, while protecting your bombers, feel very well made. The game certainly needs polished, therefore I would like to see where it goes. Please keep them coming, i want to see more.

Posted: December 12, 2013
												An inteligent, fast, smooth, and unfailingly beautiful game.  The game is small for the sheer enjoyment it brings, and with the Mega Bundle coming wth the full soundtrack and a kick♥♥♥♥♥artbook, it's what I recommend to buy.  This game is an excelent sci-fi experience in a rich and well rendered universe, the characters are distinguished but not obtrusive, letting the game speak for itself, and boy does it.  Enemies are inovative when given the chance to be, and showing any weakness will result on them mercilessly pursuing you.  Not to mention the incredibly active and powerful capital ships that power through space as you dart around every nook and cranny chasing enemy fighter craft away from your ship's critical systems and opening enemy ships up for attack.Chase and dogfight your way through swarms of enemy fighters, then switch to 'Strike Suit Mode' and completely erradicate the lot.I recommend this for any space combat fan, even if dogfights aren't your thing, the vistas, music, and watching massive ships slug it out around you is well worth the price.

Posted: October 4, 2013
												This game falls into the ''criminally underrated'' category. Remember when IGN gave Godhand a 3 when everyone else gave it a 7 or 8? It's kinda like that. I'm not gonna spend too much time on this, but the reviewers that gave it a low score did so because they are inept at playing anything harder than Mario. ''It's too hard'' was the MAIN complaint, and it's pathetic because it's not.Anyway, think Star Fox 64's 'all-range mode', but with a lot more enemies. You get 13 missions with an unfolding plot, and upgrades along the way that are unlocked by completing optional objectives that present some difficulty, but hardly the difficulty the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥reviewers say it posseses. You're given objectives in the middle of the mission, but it boils down to killing♥♥♥♥♥♥and blowing up big ships. Each mission varies up the scenario to avoid repetetiveness: protecting a fleet, taking out a ship in particular (or protecting it), taking out incoming torpedos, loss of missile systems. Just a tip: press the camera button (default is 'C') to go into first person. You have to do this for both your fighter and the Strike Suit, otherwise you're in first person in fighter mode and third person in Strike mode. It makes the fighting a lot more intense and increases that sense of inertia.Incredibly fun; highly recommended; intense dogfighting on dogfighting action; buy it now.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												The game didn't leave a good impression on me early in, but I stuck through it until mission 12 hoping for it to grab me, and now I'm done with it.  The game just isn't well designed, and mission 12 fully expressed that to me.  The weapons you get are limited in selection throughout the level.  The objectives and things you do rarely change and deviate from a formula they repeat every other level or 2.  It's basically defend X, attack X, or attack turrets on X to then get to attack X afterwards.Worse yet is on larger vehicles you're supposed to destroy you get little in terms of visual or auditory feedback that you're actually doing decent damage yourself, or if it's just your friendly ally ships.  When the objectives change, the game will do a poor job explaining what you actualy need to do, and point out targets that don't remotely matter to actually finishing it.  The game just does nothing remarkeable outside your strike suite can lock on, and let you paint multiple targets to fire a large missile barrage.  Fun for the first few times, but quickly becomes a tedious activity, as you'll use it a bunch to ween down health on ships with inflated HP.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												This game is really great. It has all the features of space combat simulation, and adds an extra gameplay improvement with the Strike Suit's strike mode.Pursuit mode is dynamic both when you're against fighters and capital ships (the big ships). The targeting system is very efficient and allows you to easily spot the best target. Strike mode adds a new gameplay with a different (and more interesting) movement control (especially efficient against capital ships) and deadly weapons very useful against fighters.The thirteen missions have a wide variety of objectives which make every one feel unique, and the improvement of both your ship and your pilot's abilities give it a high level of replayability.Even better with a joystick, in first person view.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												I really want to recommend this game. I really do. But I can't. While it is fun to play, there's a few poins that, in my opinion, reduce the fun significantly.+ Gameplay is fun (most of the time).+ Graphics and sounds are great.+ Mouse/Keyboard controls are responsive and intuitive.- Playing with controller is difficult. I have an XBox360 controller for windows. The left stick is for rolling the ship (pretty useless), the right stick is for gearing. I'd rather have it the other way round. Since you also shoot with the right hand, I play the entire game with the right hand. And there seems to be no way to change that. Thus I resorted to mouse and keyboard.- You get additional fighters during the game, and you get a "choose your ship" screen. However, even if you already have other fighters, you can't choose freely. Most of the time, you're stuck with the Strike Suit.- The Strike Suit is annoying. You play it in pursuit mode most of the time, meaning it's basically a mediocre fighter. The standard fighter you get in the beginning has more firepower. When you magically charged your Flux bar by killing enemy ships, you get a short moment of the Suit's "glory". The Suits cannons are useless and effective only against enemy fighters. When attacking a capital ship's turrets, it likes to target turrets that are on the other side of the ship (and thus can't be hit) or the ship itself (for which it has way too little firepower).- Attacking capital ships is hard, even in easy mode. You get barraged with plasma cannons, beam cannons and flak, which can tear you apart within seconds. Which is why I never made it past mission 8. The bloody carrier is too much for the flimsy Strike Suit. Especially since there are no other friendly fighters, this it focusses all of its attention at me.- I'm not exactly fond of vocals in background music.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												If your looking for a decent dogfighting game for fun this game is exhilirating except for the last mission. I found the controls a bit clunky but aside from that the only thing that continually frustrated me was the inability for me to lock on to the specific target I wanted. The brief in game explination hardly covers the use of the system adequately and knowing where those torpedos are when the entire screen is filled with explosions is quite difficult at times. All that aside I would recommend this game but wait and get it on sale. It is not a $20.00 tittle I feel it missed out on much needed development such as character development, story depth, and scenario design. Unlike what I've seen from the rest of the reviews I had no issues with the checkpoint system incorperated they were well placed and the entire point was to make sure you werent just throwing out a million rockets willy nilly so you would have the required resources to beat the end of a mission segment and reach the begining of another checkpoint. All in all the checkpoints did not hamper me in fact they were an asset once I figured out how they were placed and I knew when it was okay to waste what I had to make it to the next checkpoint after which it was acceptable to die and get more special weapon ammo and armor.

Posted: October 20, 2013
												I really enjoyed this game. Some of the main criticisms were with the control scheme and with the length of the game. Personally I got used to the controls quickly on keyboard and mouse, and if you have a controller they are supposedly better. They are also very customisable if you don't like the default system. As for the length, the game has a lot to offer for its price in my opinion, and at a reduced price you can't complain! Missions are a good length (though the checkpoint system can be rather punishing on harder missions) and it is an arcade style game in the sense that you get points for everything so replaying missions for platinum medals is encouraged.The other main criticism was that it wasn't enough like some other space flight game that the reviewer liked. Personally I don't see how this is a valid criticism for a reviewer to make who is supposed to be reviewing this game and not one that is over ten years old. This is its own game, go watch some gameplay if you are undecided, don't presume it will be like x-wing because thats what you want it to be like, you may be dissapointed.If you like bright flashy space combat and a game that rewards players that learn the mechanics and uses them instead of expecting it to be like that space game you played in 98 then pick it up!

Posted: August 1, 2015
												Strike Suit Zero starts out very strong, and hit me with a major nostalgia bomb when I first started playing it. It reminded me very strongly of several space games I had played over the years, most strongly the combat of Freelancer. The game's presentation is tight, with good visual effects and atmospheric sound design, but is plagued by poor optimization, resulting in increasingly intolerable frame stutter and worse, the video lagging behind my button inputs. In addition, over the course of only a handful of missions in the game total, the difficulty quickly spirals out of hand. The titular Strike Suit is difficult to employ properly, and oftentimes I found myself unable to take full advantage of its multi-target locking missiles. It is not unmanageable for the player to take down numerically superior enemy fighter groups, but multiple times the player is expected to protect flimsy friendly targets, some of which can be destroyed in seconds by withering hails of fire from the aforementioned enemies. If you hate escort missions as much as the average gamer does, as I do, Strike Suit Zero is liable to make you pop a blood vessel. I would be willing to forgive that, since I love space games that much- but here's where things get ugly. The frame stutter ultimately resulted in my being unable to finish the final level, and that's why I give this game a thumbs down. I was unable to finish Megabyte Punch simply because I wasn't good enough at the game, and that's not enough reason for me to dislike it, but the technical problems foisted on me by SSZ are simply unacceptable.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												This game is really great. It has all the features of space combat simulation, and adds an extra gameplay improvement with the Strike Suit's strike mode.Pursuit mode is dynamic both when you're against fighters and capital ships (the big ships). The targeting system is very efficient and allows you to easily spot the best target. Strike mode adds a new gameplay with a different (and more interesting) movement control (especially efficient against capital ships) and deadly weapons very useful against fighters.The thirteen missions have a wide variety of objectives which make every one feel unique, and the improvement of both your ship and your pilot's abilities give it a high level of replayability.Even better with a joystick, in first person view.

Posted: January 23, 2014
												First of all: This ain't a game for anyone. You absolutely NEED a gamepad/joystick and some gaming experience because this game requires some ability to be able to effectively play it.That being said, I can continue now with my considerations about the game:I've grown in a generation with lots of fantasy and mistery around intergalactic dogfights with Starwars, Starfox, Gundam, Battlestar Galactica, etc etc. and as a game I've set a minimum mark for every game that featured dogfights + space: Starfox 64 (the DS one is good, but not THAT good).Since then, I believe, I've lived in a limbo. There's been, of course some games that filled some of that gap like BF3 with it's cool dogfight, but nothing like that.Well, you may fire at me as many apples as you want but, for me, this game has set another mark for spaceship dogfight.It's more deep, more consistent, more beautiful, more realistic (control and weaponwise) and it has a playable gundam.Now to the game's basics:This game is about control. You need to understand and get used to it. It can be hard and punishing first, but after you get the hang of it, it'll all start to feel right and interesting. The story of the Strike Suit Zero is about a fight between Earth and it's colonies and you play the pilot of a new prototype fighter developed by the earthlings: the Strike Suit, a Fighter that can take the form of a Gundam for a limited time. Before the missions take place, you can (and it is recomended to) customize your weaponry according to your ship capacity (the standard strike suit has 2 slots for machine guns and 2 for missiles).The game counts with a good voice acting (but not as deep and engaging as of the Starfox's) and during the mission you'll hear a lot of conversation to keep you informed of what's happening and what you have to do and you're pretty much free to do anything (knowing that by doing anything but the mission's goal may fail the mission :P) and fly anywhere, vertically, horizontally, etc.The game is very dynamic and you'll often find yourself in a situation that you'll have to be aware of many factors (e.g: torpedoes being fired at your capital ship, fighters on your tail, enemy capital ships firing at you, mission targets, missiles being fired at you, etc etc... all at the same ♥♥♥♥ing time) and that may be a little difficult for people who aren't used to this type of game.The good:SSZ can be a little punishing for mistakes and that's good, I miss that in games. I miss that sometimes, decisions need to be made and you need to be cautious about your actions (at the same time that you need to be fast while you make your decision; The game is gorgeous, you'll often find yourself more focused into looking at the scene than on your objective; It let's you deal with situations creatively and I mean it. It's not the false creative (as in Trine), you'll actually end up having to formulate some sort of plan of action on a mission after you've failed a few times (even more if you're aiming for mission achievments which rewards you with a ship upgrade); The creators of the game said they have plenty of content ahead of us which will keep the game running (still waiting for multiplayer co-op); Not so dumb AI. Look, the AI isn't good, but I've seen worse and it can, sometimes, challenge you, so, for now, that's good enough.The bad:You'll have to pay for replayability. The game has no replay (unless you count achievment as scorehunting as replayability). To work this problem around the devs launched Strike Suit Infinity which costs almost half the original game's price and that's, uhh, not fair; The Strike Mode needs some tweaking, because while it has the function to lock-on multiple targets for your missile barrage, you'll end up in a situation where you try to lock an enemy and the game won't let you; The AI is dumb, at least dumb enought to let you shoot them down without little reaction. You'll face 2 kinds of AI in the game: The Elite and the "commoner", the Elite is actually kinda good, they can mass♥♥♥♥♥♥you, react when you tail them, bother you while you try to execute your mission etc, but that's not good enough, it could've been a lot better; in-game communication isn't so engaging. As I've said before, Starfox has set a mark and, at least at character communication, this game falls far behind to it. The voice acting is good, but you don't feel that immersion as you do with Starfox so you may feel a little betrayed :/Tl;dr:Like dogfights? Buy it.Like cool visuals? Buy it.Like balanced difficulty in games? Buy it.Like indies? Buy it.Summer Sale? Buy it.Winter Sale? Buy it.You have no money? Wait for the last 2 lines above then buy it.

Posted: February 4, 2014
												I absolutely love this game. Came into it relatively blindly. Had just done a revisit of some of my older favorites from the Wing Commander series, and was looking to jump into something similar that made use of newer technology, and SSZ happened to be on sale on Steam that day, so I made the purchase without really knowing what I was getting into. Infinitely happy that I did. The controls take a little getting used to, but the game eases you into them by giving you what's essentially a tutorial mission, followed by a few missions that are pretty light on difficulty and present you with basic forms of each fighting scenario, for example squadrons of fighters you have to take down, a capital ship you have to protect, etc. Once you get used to the key placements it's all pretty straightforward in that regard. The graphics are nothing short of spectacular both in their smoothness running and in presentation. I'm playing on a fairly decent, but not cutting edge machine, and I've experienced very few framerate issues, really only dropping slightly when so much is happening on screen that it's more than my brain can process all at once either. The sound and music are just as good, really fitting the atmosphere of the game, helping to enhance the feeling that you're taking part in massive epic space battles. There's also a good amount of replay value added in the form of mission medals and stat upgrade unlocks, that I know have me revisiting mission after mission to try for higher scores and get the unlocks/medals that I want. The only thing even remotely negative that I can say about the game is that it's pretty light on plot. The majority of the plot is communicated through text that you get both in mission briefings and post-mission reports, along with some cutscenes that take place during missions, but at times it's developed so little that I found myself scratching my head when something big happened, feeling like I didn't really know what was going on at all. But at the same time it's really not the emphasis of the game. The fast-paced large scale beautifully rendered space battles in amazingly atmospheric settings is. So basically if you're looking for something really plot heavy, this may not be the game for you, but if you're looking for a straight up space battle simulator and can live without having much of a plot to go along with it then you won't regret the purchase.

												This is a game that tries to continue a strong, and lately forgotten, pedigree which includes the likes of Wing Commander and FreeSpace.Dogfighting does bring memories of those classic games, and coupled with some very impressive visuals that borrow a bit from Homeworld (fused with some Japanese aesthetics) and a great soundtrack, it's a very strong offering.The game is unforgiving. Posted: December 26, 2013
												I remember watching Gundam and Macross Animes growing up and wishing there were video games like those. There have been many but VERY few manage to capture the scale, scope, and heart of those Mecha-Space Operas and as Space Sims died out over the past 10 years I gave up hope of seeing a great Space Opera game. Until I saw Strike Suit Zero during the Flash Sale.Strike Suit Zero isn't a TRUE space sim in the sense but the arcade style it promotes actually meshes well with the Gundam/Macross styles. Swarms of missiles flying everywhere, ships exploding, pilots screaming out death cries as their ships fall apart around them. The action is fast and intense and after babysitting you for ONE mission, SSZ kicks it into overdrive and then into crazy what the hell how do I beat this mode. HUGE thumbs up for SSZ.While I would love to see some version of Multiplayer emerge, the MOD tools are freely available for someone to attempt it, the single player is excellent and the story very thought out. The music sounded familiar to me as I played and as I did more research discovered it was composed by the same guy that did Homeworld. (A FANTASTIC Space Opera RTS in it's own right.)BUY THIS GAME!

Posted: December 26, 2013
												I'm really enjoying this game. To put it simple, It's exacly as GUNDAM SEED, just made into a game. You will notice that the captaplut is the same design :PThe missions are a bit light on text content but all is voiced. Although I believe by mission 5 you will be skipping most of them. The plot is also weak, which makes me think they did not put much time into the writing, which for this game, i'm completly fine with.As for the combat, it certainly needs polished. The fight can be caotic and if you are not familiar with your mouse sensativity you will find free aim completly unplayable. The lock on ability also needs more polished when in Striker mode, mostly tied to the free aim feature. Be aware that using the guns(rifle or energy) i did not find any trouble with it.As for striker mode and persuit mode, it feels swift, DIFFERENT(really important) and balance. On Striker Mode(humanoid, GUNDAM FUN) you feel overpowered like you should, you can simple auto target everyone with Shift and gun them, dodge enemy fire, etc. But the limit you have with it, making that fun end a little bit early ends up balancing it and making hardcore a really challenging difficulty (Although i would like more of that mode). Notice that the multiple lock on feature is very bad, u need free aim and won't detect enemies that are there. It fail completly compared to something like Zone of the Ender, so much that you wouldn't use it at all almost. As for persuit mode, It feels different, both on the weapons you use(you have more range of weapons in this mode) and the fact that you can thrust away from situations that might turn way too bad.  Here i didn't had much to complain, it feels like a fighter should feel. The space bar is perfect to change mode btw.Combat is caotic and the camera doesn't help. Then again, i like that part because it feels real, and having both 3rd person and cokpit views is a plus. The targetting system needs a bit polish, but i find the weapon selection limited. All weapons so far feel different and choice does matter, both guns and missles. But Only 2 buttons to cycle through either guns or missiles isn't enough. I would like to bind my weapons to 1-5 or similar and change them that way.As for the UI, I don't actually like it, but it does the job. I would change many things, but those that I feel that pass personal preference and became somewhat damaging to the player are the fact that your weapons are display through text. Each should have a little image, a machine gun and a rail gun, a Rocket and a Seeker missile, for exemple, that would allow quick recognition of the weapon selected. This doesn't affect guns too much(your aim changes acordingly) but the missile selection is harder than it needs to be.Lastly, regarding the aim i would like to see priority targets more distiguish. The game targetting is somewhat good, but it 3D icons suffer from the same problem games like BF4 and others. Its hard to target exacly what u want quickly or while dealing with an interceptor or changing targets.To Conclude, I found this game alot of fun. The gameplay is fast, challenging and each feature feels different. Although there are not that many types of targets(don't expect 5 types of inteceptors, 10 types of carriers, like in ZotE), the missions are sufficiently different and the form you tackle a interceptor squad, or a carrier or a full on base with carriers and squads, while protecting your bombers, feel very well made. The game certainly needs polished, therefore I would like to see where it goes. Please keep them coming, i want to see more.

Posted: February 4, 2014
												I absolutely love this game. Came into it relatively blindly. Had just done a revisit of some of my older favorites from the Wing Commander series, and was looking to jump into something similar that made use of newer technology, and SSZ happened to be on sale on Steam that day, so I made the purchase without really knowing what I was getting into. Infinitely happy that I did. The controls take a little getting used to, but the game eases you into them by giving you what's essentially a tutorial mission, followed by a few missions that are pretty light on difficulty and present you with basic forms of each fighting scenario, for example squadrons of fighters you have to take down, a capital ship you have to protect, etc. Once you get used to the key placements it's all pretty straightforward in that regard. The graphics are nothing short of spectacular both in their smoothness running and in presentation. I'm playing on a fairly decent, but not cutting edge machine, and I've experienced very few framerate issues, really only dropping slightly when so much is happening on screen that it's more than my brain can process all at once either. The sound and music are just as good, really fitting the atmosphere of the game, helping to enhance the feeling that you're taking part in massive epic space battles. There's also a good amount of replay value added in the form of mission medals and stat upgrade unlocks, that I know have me revisiting mission after mission to try for higher scores and get the unlocks/medals that I want. The only thing even remotely negative that I can say about the game is that it's pretty light on plot. The majority of the plot is communicated through text that you get both in mission briefings and post-mission reports, along with some cutscenes that take place during missions, but at times it's developed so little that I found myself scratching my head when something big happened, feeling like I didn't really know what was going on at all. But at the same time it's really not the emphasis of the game. The fast-paced large scale beautifully rendered space battles in amazingly atmospheric settings is. So basically if you're looking for something really plot heavy, this may not be the game for you, but if you're looking for a straight up space battle simulator and can live without having much of a plot to go along with it then you won't regret the purchase.

Posted: December 16, 2016
												Note: This is my impression after playing the base game without DLC or the Director's Cut, depending on the changes in the Director's Cut, some of these complaihnts may have been resolved.A space game in the vein of games like Star Wars: Rouge Squadron or Star Wars: X-Wing Alliance.  Due to the lack of games in this genre lately, I was greatly looking forward to this when I first heard of it.  Unfortunately, it didn't quite meet the mark.  The story starts out farcical, becomes mediocre, and then decides to be incomplete and farcical again on the final level.  When I first started playing, the controls felt too sensitive for me to fly straight, but this was solved by turning up the blind spot on the controls.  The difficulty spikes a couple times throughout the game, typically due to the targeting system not highlighting the targets you want it to in some levels, the ease of having your vision obstructed by explosions or damage preventing you from visually locating important objectives, or the dense, hyper-accurate turret concentrations on carriers.  The game also leaves you to figure out which weakpoints on large craft are actually important to kill in order to not fail the mission instead of telling you what the symbols mean.  It took me a while to come to the realization that the Strike Suit was mostly useful for its ability to kill massed enemies or bombard targets from beyond your normal range.  Also, collisions deal fixed damage regardless of speed or impact angle, which can frequently result in your instantaneous loss of all your shields from drifting too close to something while trying to kill a target.  Also, I found that it was necessary to rebind most of the weapon control keys to something else in order to not keep hitting the wrong button accidentally.Strike Suit Zero generally manages to be a game from a dead genre that reminds you that you want more games in the genre, but rarely manages to be even average at what it tries to do.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												I really want to recommend this game. I really do. But I can't. While it is fun to play, there's a few poins that, in my opinion, reduce the fun significantly.+ Gameplay is fun (most of the time).+ Graphics and sounds are great.+ Mouse/Keyboard controls are responsive and intuitive.- Playing with controller is difficult. I have an XBox360 controller for windows. The left stick is for rolling the ship (pretty useless), the right stick is for gearing. I'd rather have it the other way round. Since you also shoot with the right hand, I play the entire game with the right hand. And there seems to be no way to change that. Thus I resorted to mouse and keyboard.- You get additional fighters during the game, and you get a "choose your ship" screen. However, even if you already have other fighters, you can't choose freely. Most of the time, you're stuck with the Strike Suit.- The Strike Suit is annoying. You play it in pursuit mode most of the time, meaning it's basically a mediocre fighter. The standard fighter you get in the beginning has more firepower. When you magically charged your Flux bar by killing enemy ships, you get a short moment of the Suit's "glory". The Suits cannons are useless and effective only against enemy fighters. When attacking a capital ship's turrets, it likes to target turrets that are on the other side of the ship (and thus can't be hit) or the ship itself (for which it has way too little firepower).- Attacking capital ships is hard, even in easy mode. You get barraged with plasma cannons, beam cannons and flak, which can tear you apart within seconds. Which is why I never made it past mission 8. The bloody carrier is too much for the flimsy Strike Suit. Especially since there are no other friendly fighters, this it focusses all of its attention at me.- I'm not exactly fond of vocals in background music.

Posted: June 24, 2013
												Strike Suit Zero is influenced heavily by the classics. The ship design takes inspiration from Macross, Homeworld and Gundam, and the gameplay borrows elements from Freespace, Wing Commander and the X-Wing series. It makes a solid attempt at reintroducing what seems to be a lost genre, then makes an even bolder attempt at  adding to it. This is definitely a game for  fans of the aforementioned titles, and is highly recommended as a foreword for anyone who were to explore the mecha or space combat genres.

Posted: February 10, 2014
												Strike Suit: Zero is an awesome space fighting simulator that scratches an itch that few other games in recent times have.The story is told sparsely, which can be good or bad depending upon how focused you want to stay on the gameplay. The dual-nature of the Strike Suit is the central focus of the game, and it really does change combat completley when the ship transforms.You're given the option to unlock new weapons as you progress through the campaign which can also turn the tide in combat drastically. For most missions, you're locked to the strike suit (despite having unlocked other fighters) for the first playthrough. After the initial playthrough, the other fighters become unlocked and you can have another go at the level in a different ship if you so wish.The difficulty curve is fairly consistent, though the final level is just stupidly designed and plain boring. If you're not an utter completionist, leave the game at the second to last level and call that it.The Heroes of the Fleet DLC adds a new ship (the Marauder) and some new combat scenarios in the training simulator. Like the main campaign, the final level is horribly designed and gets to be an unfun grind session retry after retry. Up until then, the few missions in HotF are quite enjoyable and a nice change of pace.Ultimately, a great game marred by poor game design in the later levels in the developer's attempt to artificially ramp up difficulty.

Posted: December 13, 2013
												I was a big Freespace and Starlancer player back when those games were popular. I was also big into Star Fox and its Nintendo 64 counterpart, in addition to an unhealthy addicted to Earthsiege, Starsiege, and the Mechwarrior series. Suffice to say that I love space combat games and sims, and it is a genre that has sadly lacked any real entries over the last decade to speak of. Strike Suit Zero fills that niche very nicely.When I started SSZ and began playing, it took a little bit of time to re-acquire the whole 'flying in space with a mouse and keyboard' feeling, but once I got the hang of it, it felt as natural as ever. The controls are nice and tight and there isn't a lot of slop. The graphics are polished but the animations during cutscenes can be a little janky sometimes. Voice acting is of far better quality than I would have expected - if you think the voiceovers are going to be as bad as, say, X3, you're wrong. Egosoft could take a note from this game. Graphics and style are overall awesome. I love the depth-of-field/blurring effect when boosting through space in cockpit view. My only gripes - the HUD situation sucks. Honestly. I hate that it's a bar at the top of the screen. It's jarring and unnatural; I would have preferred the HUD to be integrated into the cockpit in first-person view and at the sides or bottom of the screen in third-person. My other gripe - and this is going to be kind of an assanine gripe, as it centers around a key concept in the game - is the strike suit. I hate the strike suit. It just feels like a gimmicky, juvenile anime trope. I've never enjoyed mecha anime and I've never enjoyed humanoid mechs. I've always preferred the gritty down-to-earth mechs of later BattleTech and the hercs of the Earthsiege universe, they just seem more probable and more likely to exist. But I guess it's more a matter of taste, really. In gameplay the Strike Suit mode is very helpful and incredibly powerful - you can lock on to an insane number of enemies and launch cluster rockets that obliterate everything, not to mention the big giant plasma shotgun thing that wrecks face. It's definitely fun. It's use is balanced out nicely by flux mechanic, and I have not really felt the game get easier as a result of having the strike suit. The only real gameplay-related gripe that I have about it is that in strike suit mode you are forced into third person view. I hate that.It's a hard game, too. Really hard. It goes easy on you at first, but once you get your first strike suit, all bets are off. In particular the first level that takes place in a nebula is difficult (due to the fact that sensors, radar, and lockon missiles do not work- you have to rely on dumbfire rockets and visual sight). I love difficult and challenging games. The good:- Difficult- Beautiful visuals and style- Interesting concept in the strike suit- Unlockable ships and progression- Variety in space environments keeps things from getting stale- Feels like a natural progression of the space shooter genre- Music is very catchy- Voiceovers aren't half bad- Price- IndieThe bad- HUD design and placement is awkward- Music can be repetitive at times- Strike suit... mainly on aesthetic grounds- Forced third-person view in strike suit mode- Makes you wish for a modern FreespaceThis game gets 4 out of 5 cookies from me! I look forward to the next game these guys put out. I hope they keep this genre alive and renew interest in it.

												This has been one of the most frustrating games I think I've ever owned.  Looks beautiful when in the game, but to get there, I had to set my main monitor to the Oculus Rift resolution of 1280x800 to play with the Rift.  Otherwise you end up with a small window in the upper right corner that does no good for Rift viewing.  Once in the game the menus are readable, but only if you keep your head very, very still.  Then when you think you have everything figured out, you try to tweak the little options in your menus, but ....can't figure out what controls to use in menus, can't use joystick apparently, so you're stuck taking off  the rift to try and see the keyboard, but standard keys do not work.  Had to escape out by doing a ctrl, alt, del because nothing else would let me.  I ran just the game without steam, but cannot use your Rift if you do that.  So I just went in to change all my controls to something I know, and now I'm going to try all of this again.  The main problem is probably my choice of controller, which is a Saitek X52, and when a menu pops up that says "hit button 30 to continue" I have no idea which one they are talking about.  I tried them all but nothing got me past the menu, so we'll just see what happens next. Posted: December 15, 2013
												A game from a tiny developer with a successful kickstarter project, Strike Suit Zero is an accomplishment I'm sure many will remember. What this game lacks in complexity, it more than makes up for elsewhere. If anything, all you can really complain about is that it feels as though there's just not enough of it! So you want to know what this game is, what it does, etc. Well, imagine for one moment if the RTS game Homeworld, was smooshed together with the TV series Battlestar Galactica, the pacing of Super R-Type, the mecha styling of Mobile Suit Gundam, the atmosphere and vibrance of Zone of the Enders and infused with the soul of the X3 series. Now imagine that all of that comes together in an orgy of frenetic 3d-space combat, beautiful, vibrant graphics, a challenging AI, a good selection of ships/mecha and weapons and a soundtrack reminiscent of the musical stylings of Talvin Singh.Bottom Line : If you love your twitch gaming, but also want an atmospheric, challenging, not to mention stunning, 3d space shooter with an engaging story and an AI that'll keep you on your toes, then look no further. This really is a gem, and at under a fiver on steam, you've really got no excuses if this kind of thing is your cup of tea!Overall : 9/10Audio : 9/10Graphics : 9/10Gameplay : 9/10

Posted: December 14, 2013
												While certainly not the best game I've ever played, Strike Suit Zero nevertheless scratches a space combat shooter itch that I've had since playing Tachyon: The Fringe back in the early 2000s.  Indeed, SSZ seems to borrow many elements from Tachyon, including most of the mechanics, feel, and weapons.  The graphics in the game are a bit underwhelming, looking more like a game from the late 00s, rather than the 2010s.  Still, for an independent title that was funded through Kickstarter, SSZ is definitely worth your time.  The main draw of the game--the mech transformation--is actually the least fun, in my opinion.  I greatly prefer the starfighter mode to the mech mode.  But, if you are looking for a no-frills space shooter that calls to mind the golden age of the genre, then this game is certainly worth that money, especially if you can get it on sale.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												IF this was the studios first project, I am really excited to see what they do next.  For a kickstarter project, this game is really polished.  The controls feel really good once you get used to them.  I am playing with a 360 controller for PC and now I wish that all my old experiences with space sims were with this type of controller.  The dual joysticks really work well for giving you yaw.  I really like that they have different ship types and didn't focus exclusively on the Strike Suit.  Playing the Bomber or Interceptor was really enjoyable and added more variety and depth to the missions.  It was kind of nice that they control how much time you can spend in the mecha form, but I think if they would of balanced that form better, there wouldn't of been the need.  I just have a hard time with it being a sci-fi genre and them saying you need to charge the suit by shooting stuff.  Why not just have it be a thermal cool down thing or something.  The story isn't overly exciting, the main character is just a name, although they are trying to manufacture a bit of a story with him.  The story doesn't add too much depth to the game, other than serving as a minimal segway to different types of missions.  But the gameplay is really fun, and the graphics are really beautiful.  It feels really amazing when you barrel role over to the underside of a capital ship after making a turret run over the top.  It really feels like you are playing in one of the epic sci fi movie battles.  I don't think I have had a game get this right before.If you are into the space combat sim genre, check it out.  The mech suit transformation is what this game brings to the table, along with updated controls, graphics and sound.  It makes me wish these guys had a license to redo wing commmander or tie fighter, they just need a few new writers.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												A nice refresh of the space combat genre that delivers an incredibly thrilling and fast-paced combat experience.Strike Suit Zero is indeed reminiscent of FreeSpace 2, but the addition of the ability to transform into a nimble space mech adds a whole new dimension to the experience. The game’s controls proved to be highly intuitive; it’s relatively easy to pick up, and the ships (be it fighter or mech) were an absolute joy to pilot. Once the Strike Suit is acquired, much of the challenge revolves around the careful management of flux energy, which is replenished upon successful kills, and expended when utilizing the high-powered weapons in strike mode. The story does an adequate job of tying the missions together, and even has a sufficiently interesting twist at the end. As to be expected from the genre, combat is potentially repetitive, but the game mitigates the problem by intensifying the challenge significantly as the campaign progresses, with enemy attacks becoming ever more relentless.The game's balance does leave something to be desired however, especially with regard to its roster of ships. Once the titular Strike Suit is made available, there's little in the way of incentives to warrant the selection of other ships. Furthermore, only generic information is provided on unlocked weapons and ship upgrades (granted upon completing mission-specific challenges). Without stat-related information, most of the weapons unlocked over the course of the campaign seem pointless. i.e. It's hard to justify the choice of heavier weapons when they incur penalties (like reduced projectile velocity) without delivering a discernible difference in dps.Graphics-wise, there's nothing revolutionary here. Nevertheless, it is a step forward as far as space combat sims are concerned. The game maintains a pleasantly minimalist (if somewhat Tron-esque) aesthetic. Each faction's vessels feature sufficiently distinctive designs with a good balance of details, and a number of missions are set against surprisingly breath-taking planetary backdrops. The bloom lighting effects can get over-the-top at times, but on the whole it fits the game well. If I were to nit-pick, some of the shortcomings would be:- completely static HUD portraits- inconsistent attention to detail: absurdly, some large objects like comms relays and shield generators attached to installations disappear without leaving any wreckage when destroyedThe game isn't perfect, but I personally find that it brings enough to the table to be a worthy addition to the genre. If you've been on the hunt for a new space combat simulator, this is one heck of an exhilarating ride that you wouldn't want to miss.

Posted: December 12, 2013
												Ideal for space cowboys.  Linear storyline rather than open world, but contrary to some reviews, I relish the frantic action and storytelling of SSZ.  It's such a nice change to have a game with some challenge to it.  The 3rd person view of the ships reminds me of ye olde Battlestar Galactica.  Taking out the gun turrets on the larger cruisers looks impressive.  Trying to get on the tails of your enemy using piloting skills and thrusters requires some perseverence in order to blast them into oblivion.  SSZ runs very well on my modest AMDm gpu.  It gets quite hypnotic at times, certainly not one for epileptics, and the in game audio is atmospheric.  I must admit i'm not one for the combo exploiting SSI sequel, but it's more of the same I suppose.  I think it was also this game that you can actually get skinning mods for several sci-fy favorites for!  7/10 whilst I await Elite.

Posted: December 14, 2013
												While certainly not the best game I've ever played, Strike Suit Zero nevertheless scratches a space combat shooter itch that I've had since playing Tachyon: The Fringe back in the early 2000s.  Indeed, SSZ seems to borrow many elements from Tachyon, including most of the mechanics, feel, and weapons.  The graphics in the game are a bit underwhelming, looking more like a game from the late 00s, rather than the 2010s.  Still, for an independent title that was funded through Kickstarter, SSZ is definitely worth your time.  The main draw of the game--the mech transformation--is actually the least fun, in my opinion.  I greatly prefer the starfighter mode to the mech mode.  But, if you are looking for a no-frills space shooter that calls to mind the golden age of the genre, then this game is certainly worth that money, especially if you can get it on sale.

Posted: December 13, 2013
												This has been one of the most frustrating games I think I've ever owned.  Looks beautiful when in the game, but to get there, I had to set my main monitor to the Oculus Rift resolution of 1280x800 to play with the Rift.  Otherwise you end up with a small window in the upper right corner that does no good for Rift viewing.  Once in the game the menus are readable, but only if you keep your head very, very still.  Then when you think you have everything figured out, you try to tweak the little options in your menus, but ....can't figure out what controls to use in menus, can't use joystick apparently, so you're stuck taking off  the rift to try and see the keyboard, but standard keys do not work.  Had to escape out by doing a ctrl, alt, del because nothing else would let me.  I ran just the game without steam, but cannot use your Rift if you do that.  So I just went in to change all my controls to something I know, and now I'm going to try all of this again.  The main problem is probably my choice of controller, which is a Saitek X52, and when a menu pops up that says "hit button 30 to continue" I have no idea which one they are talking about.  I tried them all but nothing got me past the menu, so we'll just see what happens next.  This game has soured my mood and I"m just about done with it.**  Edit**  After a much needed break, I returned to the game and got things configured to my liking.  The little issues are still there, like having to set my main monitor to 1280x800 but that is do-able for right now.  The game is very nice looking and responds well with the Rift and my joystick.  I changed my recomendation to YES, because its a good game to add to your library if you own an Oculus Rift.

Posted: December 16, 2016
												Note: This is my impression after playing the base game without DLC or the Director's Cut, depending on the changes in the Director's Cut, some of these complaihnts may have been resolved.A space game in the vein of games like Star Wars: Rouge Squadron or Star Wars: X-Wing Alliance.  Due to the lack of games in this genre lately, I was greatly looking forward to this when I first heard of it.  Unfortunately, it didn't quite meet the mark.  The story starts out farcical, becomes mediocre, and then decides to be incomplete and farcical again on the final level.  When I first started playing, the controls felt too sensitive for me to fly straight, but this was solved by turning up the blind spot on the controls.  The difficulty spikes a couple times throughout the game, typically due to the targeting system not highlighting the targets you want it to in some levels, the ease of having your vision obstructed by explosions or damage preventing you from visually locating important objectives, or the dense, hyper-accurate turret concentrations on carriers.  The game also leaves you to figure out which weakpoints on large craft are actually important to kill in order to not fail the mission instead of telling you what the symbols mean.  It took me a while to come to the realization that the Strike Suit was mostly useful for its ability to kill massed enemies or bombard targets from beyond your normal range.  Also, collisions deal fixed damage regardless of speed or impact angle, which can frequently result in your instantaneous loss of all your shields from drifting too close to something while trying to kill a target.  Also, I found that it was necessary to rebind most of the weapon control keys to something else in order to not keep hitting the wrong button accidentally.Strike Suit Zero generally manages to be a game from a dead genre that reminds you that you want more games in the genre, but rarely manages to be even average at what it tries to do.

Posted: November 18, 2013
												Well I really enjoyed that, the mouse and keyboard controls worked great and the combat was just the right difficulty. I really enjoyed switching targets and managing the priority of threats as they came up, as well as ensuring I was using the right weapons at the right times... it was a lot to think about whilst in the midst of a space war.. and I must admit it was really engaging. Got me very much in the mood for Freelancer, another game I have never finished, which has similar controls... ableit isn't involving huge capital ships blasting away at one another in an overarching space conflict like SSZ. The graphics and sound are perfect and it's a well put together game. I can't credit it with originality though, the music seemed to be from Homeworld, the way the capital ships duked it out with huge laser beams streaking between them.. really felt like Freespace, the controls seemed to be taken from Freelancer like I've said, the unflappable naval officers seem to be ripped out of Nexus - The jupiter incident and the narrative.... inspired by them all I'd say.Still! A good game and enjoyable, if they do a sequel I'd certainly keep an eye on it and pick it up at the right price.The Heroes of the Fleet is an enjoyable DLC revolving around simulations of key battles, mainly one's that were historically defeats for the Earth forces you pilot for, all of which took place within the main story line however the protagonist wasn't part of them. . I liked the narrative twist and enjoyed the fact they'd even *put* a thread of story throughout 6 stand alone DLC missions. I think that's commendable. These level's are hard and I found my self on the edge of my seat during the last level in particular, fun times.

												Decent space fighter sim. PROS : Impressive visualsHad some of that "one awesome fighter can take out a cap ship" feelInteresting space battles - cap ships fight each other and you're often called on to take out torpedoes and big guns on opposing ships. Weapons & ship customization, but not TOO much. Voice acting wasn't abominable. You're a transformer in space (man wut?)Bonus goals in each mission give actual in-game rewards that increase your effectiveness in subsequent missions. The bomber was a crapton of fun, even if it couldn't transform. Seroiusly, sometimes I still get on just to go torpedo stuff in its stupid face. CONS : Plot is pretty good, then takes a turn into WTF land. Transforming doesn't feel robot-y, or rather it's more like you're just transforming into another fighter that moves differently & has different weapons. Couldn't do anything robot-y like rip parts off ships or fistfight dinosaurs. Didn't feel like I was in space - fighters perpetually move forward & nobody takes advantage of inertia & lack of atmosphere. Repetition - "go blow up X thing" can get old fast. I wouldn't pay the regular $20 for it, but if it goes on sale, I'd say check this one out.

Posted: November 23, 2015
A dogfight space-sim. As pretty alright as the soundtrack is and as pretty as it looks it's not a very big game, the story's not exactly the most engaging out there, and there are only 13 pretty-short missions to go through. The mission objectives themselves are all generally the same protect-this & destroy-these missions so it can be repetitious.When it comes to the base gameplay they work and control great. The combat can get pretty intense the more enemies you're up against especially when suddenly your targets are large fleets themselves with guns covering practically every surface its got and the sudden priority is to take out the things that fire back.Surviving involves you keeping your ship's armor (health) and regenerating shield up and as far as I know there's no way of repairing your ship's armor without reloading a checkpoint or getting it repaired when told in one particular mission. The reload-checkpoint-to-recover-everything deal looked to me like an exploitable mechanic of sorts even though there aren't very many checkpoints throughout the game, especially the later missions with their longer mission times and limited amount of checkpoints.Each mission has an optional objective you can do that will unlock an upgrade but each one are just shared stat upgrades for all of the ships you have. What you're to do and what you can unlock are shown in the mission select screen upon preparing for the mission chosen. New ships and weapons are unlocked through progress of the missions.After a few missions you'll eventually unlock the "Strike Suit" ship which basically transforms into a straight-up mech (Strike Mode) if the "Flux" bar it comes with is filled enough through received or given damage. It's able to move more relatively freely in the three dimensions its got, has a very capable auto-locking targeting system on chosen targets within distance, and can target & lock-on to large numbers of targets for use of the barrage of the seeking missiles it can fire. The Flux bar starts to drain upon use of Strike Mode's firing capabilities but if used efficiently the Flux bar can prolong its usage without transforming back to ship mode.Kind of surprisingly the Strike Suit you use is the only mech in the game. No ally or enemy has anything similar although the mech may as well just be a temporary ship with a few more capabilities.There's not a whole lot else to this game outside of the well-done space-dogfighting.

Posted: December 8, 2014
												Strike Suit Zero is a well-paced mission-based arcade style space odyssey set in the distant future when humans have colonized the galaxy, and a civil war has broken out among mankind. The player plays as a reformed fighter pilot who is re-commissioned to the front lines in a desperate suicidal struggle to stop the rebel onslaught against Earth, along with their new and mysterious weapon that is literally ripping holes through entire fleets and worlds. While you have very little interaction with the enemy faction, what are incredible are the believable archetypes of the allies and friends you make along the way. You will care very much about the allies you rescue and that rescue you from the perils of interstellar warfare. With themes from several science fiction settings and ominous overtones about the rise and fall of mankind, there is plenty of depth to be excited about as you meet new characters and face new challenges. The gameplay is magnificent and convincing; once you get ahold of the strike suit, you go from being a regular pilot hanging on to life with sheer grit to a space hero like unto those in anime of this genre, hell-bent on keeping your friends and comrades alive through each and every encounter. You will hang turns, glide around gigantic ships and launch attacks so devastating that afterwards you can't help but jump up and roar with righteous vindication. To that end, the protagonist and the enemies are so quiet that you are left space to imagine you are any kind of hero or anti-hero you like, the plot ambiguous enough to let you have your own adventure while still shaping the events and circumstances you fight your way through. Are you a grizzled space cowboy back for one last ride? Or are you a bloodthirsty convict, with nothing left but a war to fight? It's up to you to impose your personal motivations on the main character. In spite of or perhaps due to these intentional gaps in information, the story telling, the sound, the visuals and the music are all clearly a labor of love and do exactly what they're intended to do: Let you have your own robot space fighter fantasy.Are there negatives? Yes, a few. The game is too short. The director's cut is oddly paced and undercuts the original vision of the game. The combat is samey and the upgrades are extremely difficult, impossible in some cases, to obtain without replaying missions later on, which greatly pads out the playtime with replay. However, as an Indi title and one of the best games so far this millennium, all of these negatives can be completely overlooked. There are plenty of modes and versions for you to satisfy your desire to dogfight and ace your way to victory, and ultimately all add up to satisfying content. Never mind how amazing some of the mods are for this game.11/10. If you like arcade shooters, sci-fi, anime, space odyssey, warfare, dogfighting, or just stupidly impressive visuals, play this game. Strike Suit Zero is a fantastic time.

Posted: February 25
												I have not played other space flight simulators extensively, so I cannot review this game based on how it compares to others in the genre. I can say that the graphics, controls, and level design do deliver on one thing - immersion.When you're making a hard turn, going upside down to try and flank the ship on your tail, the tension is real, as is the feeling in the back of your mind that you are travelling through endless, empty space. When another computer controlled ship in your squadron swings by and bails you out of something or steals your kill, it feels like a real, chaotic dogfight.Possibly the most important immersive part of the game is, once you unlock the Strike Suit, how much it really does look and feel like you are piloting a Gundam. When you first get it, with the music playing in the background and all of the swarms of enemy ships, you completely annhilate almost everything you can see. Then, in the next mission, the learning curve picks up, and you start to feel the limitations of this awesome machine. Quickly, because of how powerful the strike suit is, you get thrown into messes that are too much for the ship alone, and you have to knuckle down and enhance your skills to keep up. Meanwhile, the war rages on, and its emotional toll is felt by all.Doesn't that sound just like the plot of most Gundam shows? I was impressed by how the designers used their game's difficulty curve to reinforce the feel of being that one pilot with the super weapon on whom everything depends. This game is pretty hard, or at least it was for me, and as the best hard games do, it pushed me to get better and really hunker down to get specials from the missions so that I was well equipped enough to handle later ones.The story is nothing to write home about, and some of the combat scenarios get repetitive, especially since you often have to replay missions to get power ups. But the overall atmosphere of the game? Superb. And that makes playing it a joy, even if part of you is thinking 'torpedos? Again?'
